original: kaś cit kāntāvirahaguruṇā svādhikārapramattaḥ śāpenāstaṅgamitamahimā varṣabhogyeṇa bhartuḥ /
analyzed: kaḥ cit kāntā viraha guruṇā sva adhikāra pramattaḥ śāpena astaṅga mita mahimā varṣa bhogyeṇa bhartuḥ
translated: A certain Yaksha, separated from his beloved by the curse of his master, who was angry because he had neglected his duty, and whose power had been destroyed by a curse lasting for a year,

original: yakṣaś cakre janakatanayāsnānapuṇyodakeṣu snigdhacchāyātaruṣu vasatiṃ rāmagiryāśrameṣu // //
analyzed: yakṣaḥ cakre janakatanayā snāna puṇya udakeṣu snigdha chāyā taruṣu vasatim rāmagiri āśrameṣu
translated: lived in the hermitages on the mountain of Rama, in the holy waters where Sita bathed, and in the trees with cool shade.

original: tasminn adrau kati cid abalāviprayuktaḥ sa kāmī nītvā māsān kanakavalayabhraṃśariktaprakoṣṭhaḥ /
analyzed: tasmin adrau kati cit abalā viprayuktaḥ sa kāmī nītvā māsān kanaka valaya bhraṃśa rikta prakoṣṭhaḥ
translated: For some months, separated from his beloved, the lover, his forearms bare of golden bracelets,

original: āṣāḍhasya praśamadivase megham āśliṣṭasānuṃ vaprakrīḍāpariṇatagajaprekṣaṇīyaṃ dadarśa // //
analyzed: āṣāḍhasya praśama divase megham āśliṣṭa sānum vapra krīḍā pariṇata gaja prekṣaṇīyam dadarśa
translated: saw, on the last day of the rainy season, a cloud embracing the mountain peak, delightful to behold like an elephant sporting in the water.

original: tasya sthitvā katham api puraḥ ketakādhānahetor antarbāṣpaś ciram anucaro rājarājasya dadhyau /
analyzed: tasya sthitvā katham api puras ketaka ādhāna hetoḥ antar bāṣpaḥ ciram anucaraḥ rājarājasya dadhyau
translated: Standing before it somehow for the sake of offering a ketaki flower, the attendant of the king of the Yakshas, with tears within, reflected for a long time.

original: meghāloke bhavati sukhino 'py anyathāvṛtti cetaḥ kaṇṭhāśleṣapraṇayini jane kiṃ punar dūrasaṃsthe // //
analyzed: megha āloke bhavati sukhinaḥ u pi anyathāvṛtti cetaḥ kaṇṭha āśleṣa praṇayini jane kim punar dūra saṃsthe
translated: The mind of even a happy person becomes otherwise at the sight of a cloud; what to speak of a person who is attached to embracing the neck (of his beloved) and is far away?

original: pratyāsanne nabhasi dayitājīvitālambanārthī jīmūtena svakuśalamayīṃ hārayiṣyan pravṛttim /
analyzed: pratyāsanne nabhasi dayitā jīvita ālambana arthī jīmūtena sva kuśala mayīm hārayiṣyan pravṛttim
translated: When the cloud was near, desiring to convey his well-being in the form of a message to his beloved, the support of his life,

original: sa pratyagraiḥ kuṭajakusumaiḥ kalpitārghāya tasmai prītaḥ prītipramukhavacanaṃ svāgataṃ vyājahāra // //
analyzed: sa pratyagraiḥ kuṭaja kusumaiḥ kalpita arghāya tasmai prītaḥ prīti pramukha vacanam svāgatam vyājahāra
translated: He was delighted and welcomed him with a friendly greeting, offering him the hospitality prepared with freshly picked Kutaja flowers.

original: dhūmajyotiḥsalilamarutāṃ saṃnipātaḥ kva meghaḥ saṃdeśārthāḥ kva paṭukaraṇaiḥ prāṇibhiḥ prāpaṇīyāḥ /
analyzed: dhūma jyotiḥ salila marutām saṃnipātaḥ kva meghaḥ saṃdeśa arthāḥ kva paṭu karaṇaiḥ prāṇibhiḥ prāpaṇīyāḥ
translated: Where is a cloud, a combination of smoke, light, water, and wind? And where are messages to be conveyed by beings with keen senses?

original: ity autsukyād aparigaṇayan guhyakas taṃ yayāce kāmārtā hi praṇayakṛpaṇāś cetanācetaneṣu // //
analyzed: iti autsukyāt a parigaṇayan guhyakaḥ tam yayāce kāma ārtāḥ hi praṇaya kṛpaṇāḥ cetana acetaneṣu
translated: Thus, disregarding this out of eagerness, the Guhyaka implored him. For those afflicted by love are miserly with affection towards conscious and unconscious beings.

original: jātaṃ vaṃśe bhuvanavidite puṣkarāvartakānāṃ jānāmi tvāṃ prakṛtipuruṣaṃ kāmarūpaṃ maghonaḥ /
analyzed: jātam vaṃśe bhuvana vidite puṣkarāvartakānām jānāmi tvām prakṛti puruṣam kāmarūpam maghonaḥ
translated: Born in the lineage known throughout the world of the Pushkaravartas, I know you to be the natural man, able to assume any form at will, of Maghavat.

original: tenārthitvaṃ tvayi vidhivaśād dūrabandhur gato 'haṃ yācñā vandhyā varam adhiguṇe nādhame labdhakāmā // //
analyzed: tena arthi tvam tvayi vidhi vaśāt dūra bandhuḥ gataḥ ham yācñā vandhyā varam adhiguṇe nā adhame labdha kāmā
translated: Therefore, due to the power of fate, I have come to you for help, a distant relative. A request is fruitless for one of high qualities, not for one of low desires.

original: saṃtaptānāṃ tvam asi śaraṇaṃ tat payoda priyāyāḥ saṃdeśaṃ me hara dhanapatikrodhaviśleṣitasya /
analyzed: saṃtaptānām tvam asi śaraṇam tat payoda priyāyāḥ saṃdeśam me hara dhanapati krodha viśleṣitasya
translated: O cloud, you are the refuge of those tormented by love. Carry my message, separated by the anger of the lord of wealth.

original: gantavyā te vasatir alakā nāma yakṣeśvarāṇāṃ bāhyodyānasthitaharaśiraścandrikādhautaharmyā // //
analyzed: gantavyā te vasatiḥ alakā nāma yakṣa īśvarāṇām bāhya udyāna sthita hara śiraḥ candrikā dhauta harmyā
translated: You must go to his abode named Alakā, the dwelling places of the lords of the Yakshas, their mansions washed by the moonlight from the head of Hara situated in the outer gardens.

original: tvām ārūḍhaṃ pavanapadavīm udgṛhītālakāntāḥ prekṣiṣyante pathikavanitāḥ pratyayād āśvasantyaḥ /
analyzed: tvām ārūḍham pavana padavīm udgṛhīta alaka antāḥ prekṣiṣyante pathika vanitāḥ pratyayāt āśvasantyaḥ
translated: The wives of travellers, reassured by their faith, will watch you as you mount the path of the wind, your locks streaming behind you.

original: kaḥ saṃnaddhe virahavidhurāṃ tvayy upekṣeta jāyāṃ na syād anyo 'py aham iva jano yaḥ parādhīnavṛttiḥ // //
analyzed: kaḥ saṃnaddhe viraha vidhurām tvayi upekṣeta jāyām na syāt aham iva janaḥ yaḥ para adhīna vṛttiḥ
translated: Who, when you are ready to depart, would neglect his wife, already distraught by separation? There is no one else like me, who am dependent on another for my livelihood.

original: āpṛcchasva priyasakham amuṃ tuṅgam āliṅgya śailaṃ vandyaiḥ puṃsāṃ raghupatipadair aṅkitaṃ mekhalāsu /
analyzed: āpṛcchasva priya sakham amum tuṅgam āliṅgya śailam vandyaiḥ puṃsām raghupati padaiḥ aṅkitam mekhalāsu
translated: Embracing this lofty mountain, your dear friend, marked on its slopes with the revered footprints of Rāghava, take leave of it.

original: kāle kāle bhavati bhavatā yasya saṃyogam etya snehavyaktiś ciravirahajaṃ muñcato bāṣpam uṣṇam // //🔽mandaṃ mandaṃ nudati pavanaś cānukūlo yathā tvāṃ vāmaś cāyaṃ nadati madhuraṃ cātakas toyagṛdhnuḥ /
analyzed: kāle kāle bhavati bhavatā yasya saṃyogam etya sneha vyaktiḥ cira viraha jam muñcataḥ bāṣpam uṣṇam  mandam mandam nudati pavanaḥ ca anukūlaḥ yathā tvām vāmaḥ ca ayam nadati madhuram cātakaḥ toya gṛdhnuḥ
translated: From time to time, when you come into contact with him, the expression of affection of one who sheds hot tears of joy after a long separation will appear on his face.🔽A gentle breeze blows in your favour, and this friendly curlew cries sweetly, eager for water.

original: garbhādhānasthiraparicayā nūnam ābaddhamālāḥ seviṣyante nayanasubhagaṃ khe bhavantaṃ balākāḥ // //
analyzed: garbhādhāna sthira paricayāḥ nūnam ābaddha mālāḥ seviṣyante nayana subhagam khe bhavantam balākāḥ
translated: The female cranes, who know you well from your steady visits to the place of impregnation, will surely follow you, their garlands freshly strung, as you move through the sky, delightful to the eyes.

original: tāṃ cāvaśyaṃ divasagaṇanātatparām ekapatnīm avyāpannām avihatagatir drakṣyasi bhrātṛjāyām /
analyzed: tām ca avaśyam divasa gaṇanā tatparām ekapatnīm a vyāpannām avihata gatiḥ drakṣyasi bhrātṛ jāyām
translated: And you will certainly see your brother's wife, who is devoted to her husband, who is faithful to him, and who is counting the days, her path unimpeded.

original: āśābandhaḥ kusumasadṛśaṃ prāyaśo hy aṅganānāṃ sadyaḥpātapraṇayi hṛdayaṃ viprayoge ruṇaddhi // //🔽kartuṃ yac ca prabhavati mahīm ucchilindhrām avandhyaṃ tac chrutvā te śravaṇasubhagaṃ garjitaṃ mānasotkāḥ /
analyzed: āśābandhaḥ kusuma sadṛśam prāyaśas hi aṅganānām sadyaḥpāta praṇayi hṛdayam viprayoge ruṇaddhi  kartum yat ca prabhavati mahīm ucchilindhrām avandhyam tat śrutvā te śravaṇa subhagam garjitam mānasa utkāḥ
translated: The hope of reunion is like a flower to women, generally; but when separation is imminent, it chokes their hearts.🔽And when you are able to make your thunder fruitful by bringing rain on the earth, then,🔽eager with longing, having taken as provisions the severed lotus-stalks, your royal swans will meet you in the sky and become your companions,

original: ā kailāsād bisakisalayacchedapātheyavantaḥ saṃpatsyante nabhasi bhavato rājahaṃsāḥ sahāyāḥ // //
analyzed: ā kailāsāt bisa kisalaya cheda pātheyavantaḥ saṃpatsyante nabhasi bhavataḥ rājahaṃsāḥ sahāyāḥ
translated: as far as Kailasa.

original: mārgaṃ tāvac chṛṇu kathayatas tvatprayāṇānukūlaṃ saṃdeśaṃ me tadanu jalada śroṣyasi śrotrapeyam /
analyzed: mārgam tāvat śṛṇu kathayataḥ tvad prayāṇa anukūlam saṃdeśam me tadanu jalada śroṣyasi śrotra peyam
translated: First listen to me telling you the way, favorable to your journey; then, O cloud, you will hear my message, which is fit to be drunk in with the ears.

original: khinnaḥ khinnaḥ śikhariṣu padaṃ nyasya gantāsi yatra kṣīṇaḥ kṣīṇaḥ parilaghu payaḥ srotasāṃ copabhujya // //
analyzed: khinnaḥ khinnaḥ śikhariṣu padam nyasya gantāsi yatra kṣīṇaḥ kṣīṇaḥ parilaghu payaḥ srotasām ca upabhujya
translated: Weary, weary, placing your foot on the mountain-peaks, you will go where you will be exhausted, exhausted, and then drink the water of the streams.

original: adreḥ śṛṅgaṃ harati pavanaḥ kiṃ svid ity unmukhībhir dṛṣṭotsāhaś cakitacakitaṃ mugdhasiddhāṅganābhiḥ /
analyzed: adreḥ śṛṅgam harati pavanaḥ kim svid iti unmukhībhiḥ dṛṣṭa utsāhaḥ cakita cakitam mugdha siddha aṅganābhiḥ
translated: The innocent wives of the Siddhas, seeing you, will look up with eyes wide with wonder, thinking, Is the wind carrying off the peak of the mountain?

original: sthānād asmāt sarasaniculād utpatodaṅmukhaḥ khaṃ diṅnāgānāṃ pathi pariharan sthūlahastāvalehān // //
analyzed: sthānāt asmāt sarasa niculāt utpata udak mukhaḥ kham diṅnāgānām pathi pariharan sthūla hasta avalehān
translated: Rising from this place, the lake with its thickets, and facing north, you should cross the path of the quarter-elephants, licking the tips of their trunks.

original: ratnacchāyāvyatikara iva prekṣyam etat purastād valmīkāgrāt prabhavati dhanuṣkhaṇḍam ākhaṇḍalasya /
analyzed: ratna chāyā vyatikare iva prekṣyam etat purastāt valmīka agrāt prabhavati dhanuṣkhaṇḍam ākhaṇḍalasya
translated: In front, you should see that which looks like a mixture of the reflections of jewels, the bow of Indra rising from the top of an ant-hill.

original: yena śyāmaṃ vapur atitarāṃ kāntim āpatsyate te barheṇeva sphuritarucinā gopaveśasya viṣṇoḥ // //
analyzed: yena śyāmam vapuḥ atitarām kāntim āpatsyate te barheṇa iva sphurita rucinā gopa veśasya viṣṇoḥ
translated: By which the dark body of Vishnu, in the guise of a cowherd, will attain a beauty far greater, as if with a peacock feather shining.

original: tvayy āyattaṃ kṛṣiphalam iti bhrūvilāsānabhijñaiḥ prītisnigdhair janapadavadhūlocanaiḥ pīyamānaḥ /🔽sadyaḥsīrotkaṣaṇasurabhi kṣetram āruhya mālaṃ kiṃ cit paścād pravalaya gatiṃ bhūya evottareṇa // //
analyzed: tvayi āyattam kṛṣi phalam iti bhrū vilāsa anabhijñaiḥ prīti snigdhaiḥ janapada vadhū locanaiḥ pīyamānaḥ  sadyas sīra utkaṣaṇa surabhi kṣetram āruhya mālam kim cit paścāt pravalaya gatim bhūyas evā uttareṇa
translated: You are to be drunk by the eyes of country girls, affectionate with love, ignorant of the play of eyebrows, thinking that the fruit of agriculture depends on you.🔽Having mounted the field fragrant with the immediate plowing, increase your speed a little to the west, and then again to the north.

original: tvām āsārapraśamitavanopaplavaṃ sādhu mūrdhnā vakṣyaty adhvaśramaparigataṃ sānumān āmrakūṭaḥ /
analyzed: tvām āsāra praśamita vana upaplavam sādhu mūrdhnā vakṣyati adhva śrama parigatam sānumān āmrakūṭaḥ
translated: Amuka-kūṭa, with its peaks, will properly bear you on its head, you who have quelled the forest conflagration with showers, and who are tired from the journey.

original: na kṣudro 'pi prathamasukṛtāpekṣayā saṃśrayāya prāpte mitre bhavati vimukhaḥ kiṃ punar yas tathoccaiḥ // //
analyzed: na kṣudraḥ pi prathama sukṛta apekṣayā saṃśrayāya prāpte mitre bhavati vimukhaḥ kim punar yaḥ tathā uccais
translated: Even a small person, out of regard for the first good deed, does not turn away to find shelter when a friend has arrived; how much more so one as lofty as you!

original: channopāntaḥ pariṇataphaladyotibhiḥ kānanāmrais tvayy ārūḍhe śikharam acalaḥ snigdhaveṇīsavarṇe /
analyzed: channa upāntaḥ pariṇata phala dyotibhiḥ kānana āmraiḥ tvayi ārūḍhe śikharam acalaḥ snigdha veṇī savarṇe
translated: When you have climbed the peak of the mountain, O you who are the colour of a glossy braid, its sides will be hidden by the mango trees that bear ripe fruit.

original: nūnaṃ yāsyaty amaramithunaprekṣaṇīyām avasthāṃ madhye śyāmaḥ stana iva bhuvaḥ śeṣavistārapāṇḍuḥ // //
analyzed: nūnam yāsyati amara mithuna prekṣaṇīyām avasthām madhye śyāmaḥ stanaḥ iva bhuvaḥ śeṣa vistāra pāṇḍuḥ
translated: The mountain will surely attain a state fit to be seen by couples of immortals, with its middle dark like a woman's breast, and its sides white like the rest of the earth.

original: sthitvā tasmin vanacaravadhūbhuktakuñje muhūrtaṃ toyotsargadrutataragatis tatparaṃ vartma tīrṇaḥ /
analyzed: sthitvā tasmin vanacara vadhū bhukta kuñje muhūrtam toya utsarga drutatara gatiḥ tad param vartma tīrṇaḥ
translated: Having stayed for a moment in that grove, frequented by the wives of the forest-dwellers, and having crossed that path with a speed hastened by the downpour of water,

original: revāṃ drakṣyasy upalaviṣame vindhyapāde viśīrṇāṃ bhakticchedair iva viracitāṃ bhūtim aṅge gajasya // //
analyzed: revām drakṣyasi upala viṣame vindhya pāde viśīrṇām bhakti chedaiḥ iva viracitām bhūtim aṅge gajasya
translated: you will see the Revā river on the uneven Vindhya foothills, broken into pieces as if it were the ash smeared on the body of Śiva.

original: tasyās tiktair vanagajamadair vāsitaṃ vāntavṛṣṭir jambūṣaṇḍapratihatarayaṃ toyam ādāya gaccheḥ /
analyzed: tasyāḥ tiktaiḥ vana gaja madaiḥ vāsitam vānta vṛṣṭiḥ jambu ṣaṇḍa pratihata rayam toyam ādāya gaccheḥ
translated: Having drunk the water perfumed with the bitter scent of wild elephants, and having its current checked by the clusters of rose-apple trees, you should go.

original: antaḥsāraṃ ghana tulayituṃ nānilaḥ śakṣyati tvāṃ riktaḥ sarvo bhavati hi laghuḥ pūrṇatā gauravāya // //
analyzed: antar sāram ghana tulayitum nā anilaḥ śakṣyati tvām riktaḥ sarvaḥ bhavati hi laghuḥ pūrṇa tā gauravāya
translated: O cloud, the wind will not be able to weigh you, who are full of essence, for an empty one is always light, but fullness is heavy.

original: nīpaṃ dṛṣṭvā haritakapiśaṃ kesarair ardharūḍhair āvirbhūtaprathamamukulāḥ kandalīś cānukaccham /
analyzed: nīpam dṛṣṭvā harita kapiśam kesaraiḥ ardha rūḍhaiḥ āvirbhūta prathama mukulāḥ kandalīḥ ca anukaccham
translated: Having seen the neem tree with its half-grown filaments, tawny like a green monkey, and the banana plants with their buds just appearing,

original: dagdhāraṇyeṣv adhikasurabhiṃ gandham āghrāya corvyāḥ sāraṅgās te jalalavamucaḥ sūcayiṣyanti mārgam // //
analyzed: dagdha araṇyeṣu adhika surabhim gandham āghrāya ca urvyāḥ sāraṅgāḥ te jala lava mucaḥ sūcayiṣyanti mārgam
translated: The sārasa birds, smelling the fragrance of the burnt fields, more intense than that of the earth, and dropping drops of water, will show you the way.

original: utpaśyāmi drutam api sakhe matpriyārthaṃ yiyāsoḥ kālakṣepaṃ kakubhasurabhau parvate parvate te /🔽śuklāpāṅgaiḥ sanayanajalaiḥ svāgatīkṛtya kekāḥ pratyudyātaḥ katham api bhavān gantum āśu vyavasyet // //🔽pāṇḍucchāyopavanavṛtayaḥ ketakaiḥ sūcibhinnair nīḍārambhair gṛhabalibhujām ākulagrāmacaityāḥ /
analyzed: utpaśyāmi drutam api sakhe mad priya artham yiyāsoḥ kāla kṣepam kakubha surabhau parvate parvate te  śukla apāṅgaiḥ sa nayanajalaiḥ svāgatīkṛtya kekāḥ pratyudyātaḥ katham api bhavān gantum āśu vyavasyet  pāṇḍu chāyā upavana vṛtayaḥ ketakaiḥ sūci bhinnaiḥ nīḍa ārambhaiḥ gṛha balibhujām ākula grāma caityāḥ
translated: I see, friend, that even if you are in a hurry to go for my sake, you will waste time on every mountain fragrant with directions,🔽and having welcomed the peacocks with your eyes full of tears, you will somehow manage to set out quickly.🔽The villages will be crowded with the houses of the sacrificial priests, with ketaka flowers pricked by needles, and with the nests of the village crows.

original: tvayy āsanne phalapariṇatiśyāmajambūvanāntāḥ saṃpatsyante katipayadinasthāyihaṃsā daśārṇāḥ // //
analyzed: tvayi āsanne phala pariṇati śyāma jambū vana antāḥ saṃpatsyante katipaya dina sthāyi haṃsāḥ daśārṇāḥ
translated: When you are near, the people of Dasharna, with the swans staying for a few days, will be successful, with the mango groves dark with the ripening of the fruit at the end.

original: teṣāṃ dikṣu prathitavidiśālakṣaṇāṃ rājadhānīṃ gatvā sadyaḥ phalam avikalaṃ kāmukatvasya labdhā /
analyzed: teṣām dikṣu prathita vidiśā lakṣaṇām rājadhānīm gatvā sadyas phalam avikalam kāmuka tvasya labdhā
translated: Having gone to their capital, famous in all directions, you will immediately obtain the complete fruit of being a lover.

original: tīropāntastanitasubhagaṃ pāsyasi svādu yat tat sabhrūbhaṅgaṃ mukham iva payo vetravatyāś calormi // //
analyzed: tīra upānta stanita subhagam pāsyasi svādu yat tat sa bhrū bhaṅgam mukham iva payaḥ vetravatyāḥ cala ūrmi
translated: You will drink the water of the Vetravatī, sweet and pleasant with the murmuring on its banks, with its moving waves like a face with arched brows.

original: nīcairākhyaṃ girim adhivases tatra viśrāmahetos tvatsamparkāt pulakitam iva prauḍhapuṣpaiḥ kadambaiḥ /🔽yaḥ paṇyastrīratiparimalodgāribhir nāgarāṇām uddāmāni prathayati śilāveśmabhir yauvanāni // //
analyzed: nīcairākhyam girim adhivaseḥ tatra viśrāma hetoḥ tvad samparkāt pulakitam iva prauḍha puṣpaiḥ kadambaiḥ  yaḥ paṇya strī rati parimala udgāribhiḥ nāgarāṇām uddāmāni prathayati śilā veśmabhiḥ yauvanāni
translated: You should stay at the mountain called Nīca, which, as if thrilled at your contact, displays its full-blown kadamba flowers.🔽It is the mountain where the mansions of the Nāgaras, exuding the fragrance of the love of courtesans, proclaim their exuberant youth.

original: viśrāntaḥ san vraja vananadītīrajātāni siñcann udyānānāṃ navajalakaṇair yūthikājālakāni /
analyzed: viśrāntaḥ san vraja vana nadī tīra jātāni siñcan udyānānām nava jala kaṇaiḥ yūthikā jālakāni
translated: Having rested, go on sprinkling with fresh water-drops the jasmine creepers in the gardens on the banks of forest-streams.

original: gaṇḍasvedāpanayanarujāklāntakarṇotpalānāṃ chāyādānāt kṣaṇaparicitaḥ puṣpalāvīmukhānām // //🔽vakraḥ panthā yad api bhavataḥ prasthitasyottarāśāṃ saudhotsaṅgapraṇayavimukho mā sma bhūr ujjayinyāḥ /🔽vidyuddāmasphuritacakitais tatra paurāṅganānāṃ lolāpāṅgair yadi na ramase locanair vañcito 'si // //
analyzed: gaṇḍa sveda apanayana rujā klānta karṇa utpalānām chāyā dānāt kṣaṇa paricitaḥ puṣpalāvī mukhānām  vakraḥ panthāḥ yat api bhavataḥ prasthitasya uttara āśām saudha utsaṅga praṇaya vimukhaḥ mā sma bhūḥ ujjayinyāḥ  vidyut dāma sphurita cakitaiḥ tatra paura aṅganānām lola apāṅgaiḥ yadi na ramase locanaiḥ vañcitaḥ si
translated: You will be for a moment a friend to the faces of the flower-girls, tired by the pain of removing the sweat from their cheeks, by giving them shade.🔽Though the path to the north is winding, do not be averse to the embrace of the palace-walls of Ujjayinī.🔽If you are not delighted by the restless side-glances of the eyes of the city-women, frightened by the flashing of the lightning, you are cheated.

original: vīcikṣobhastanitavihagaśreṇikāñcīguṇāyāḥ saṃsarpantyāḥ skhalitasubhagaṃ darśitāvartanābheḥ /
analyzed: vīci kṣobha stanita vihaga śreṇi kāñcī guṇāyāḥ saṃsarpantyāḥ skhalita subhagam darśita āvarta nābheḥ
translated: Of the river which has for its girdle the line of birds singing in the agitation of its waves, which shows its navel in the form of eddies as it crawls along gracefully,

original: nirvindhyāyāḥ pathi bhava rasābhyantaraḥ saṃnipatya strīṇām ādyaṃ praṇayavacanaṃ vibhramo hi priyeṣu // //
analyzed: nirvindhyāyāḥ pathi bhava rasa abhyantaraḥ saṃnipatya strīṇām ādyam praṇaya vacanam vibhramaḥ hi priyeṣu
translated: On the way to Nirvindhya, be full of rasa (passion) by approaching the women. For, in the case of lovers, confusion is the first expression of love.

original: veṇībhūtapratanusalilāṃ tām atītasya sindhuṃ pāṇḍucchāyāṃ taṭaruhatarubhraṃśibhir jīrṇaparṇaiḥ /
analyzed: veṇī bhūta pratanu salilām tām atītasya sindhum pāṇḍu chāyām taṭa ruha taru bhraṃśibhiḥ jīrṇa parṇaiḥ
translated: Having crossed that river, the water of which is thin like a braid, pale in color due to the falling old leaves of the trees on its banks,

original: saubhāgyaṃ te subhaga virahāvasthayā vyañjayantīṃ kārśyaṃ yena tyajati vidhinā sa tvayaivopapādyaḥ // //
analyzed: saubhāgyam te subhaga viraha avasthayā vyañjayantīm kārśyam yena tyajati vidhinā sa tvayā evā upapādyaḥ
translated: you should bring about that emaciation by some means, O fortunate one, which the river, expressing your good fortune by its condition of separation, gives up.

original: prāpyāvantīn udayanakathākovidagrāmavṛddhān pūrvoddiṣṭām anusara purīṃ śrīviśālāṃ viśālām /
analyzed: prāpya avantīn udayana kathā kovida grāma vṛddhān pūrva uddiṣṭām anusara purīm śrīviśālām viśālām
translated: Having reached Avanti, the old men of the villages who are well-versed in the stories of Udayana, follow the path leading to the famous city of Vishala, as previously indicated.

original: svalpībhūte sucaritaphale svargiṇāṃ gāṃ gatānāṃ śeṣaiḥ puṇyair hṛtam iva divaḥ kāntimat khaṇḍam ekam // //
analyzed: su alpībhūte su carita phale svargiṇām gām gatānām śeṣaiḥ puṇyaiḥ hṛtam iva divaḥ kāntimat khaṇḍam ekam
translated: When the fruits of good deeds of the heaven-dwellers have become small and they have gone to the earth, it is as if a radiant piece of heaven has been taken away by the remaining merits.

original: dīrghīkurvan paṭu madakalaṃ kūjitaṃ sārasānāṃ pratyūṣeṣu sphuṭitakamalāmodamaitrīkaṣāyaḥ /
analyzed: dīrghīkurvan paṭu mada kalam kūjitam sārasānām pratyūṣeṣu sphuṭita kamala āmoda maitrī kaṣāyaḥ
translated: Lengthening the loud and sweet cries of the cranes at dawn, tinged with the fragrance of the blooming lotuses,

original: yatra strīṇāṃ harati surataglānim aṅgānukūlaḥ siprāvātaḥ priyatama iva prārthanācāṭukāraḥ // //
analyzed: yatra strīṇām harati surata glānim aṅga anukūlaḥ siprā vātaḥ priyatamaḥ iva prārthanā cāṭu kāraḥ
translated: where the Siprā breeze, favorable to the limbs, removes the fatigue of lovemaking of the women, like a beloved lover flattering with requests.

original: jālodgīrṇair upacitavapuḥ keśasaṃskāradhūmair bandhuprītyā bhavanaśikhibhir dattanṛttopahāraḥ /
analyzed: jāla udgīrṇaiḥ upacita vapuḥ keśa saṃskāra dhūmaiḥ bandhu prītyā bhavana śikhibhiḥ datta nṛtta upahāraḥ
translated: Your body nourished by the smoke of hairdressing from the locks released by the net, having offered a dance as a present out of affection for your friend,

original: harmyeṣv asyāḥ kusumasurabhiṣv adhvakhinnāntarātmā nītvā rātriṃ lalitavanitāpādarāgāṅkiteṣu // //
analyzed: harmyeṣu asyāḥ kusuma surabhiṣu adhva khinna antarātmā nītvā rātrim lalita vanitā pāda rāga aṅkiteṣu
translated: having spent the night in her mansions fragrant with flowers, your heart weary from traveling, marked with the red lac from the feet of charming young women,

original: bhartuḥ kaṇṭhacchavir iti gaṇaiḥ sādaraṃ dṛśyamāṇaḥ puṇyaṃ yāyās tribhuvanaguror dhāma caṇḍeśvarasya /
analyzed: bhartuḥ kaṇṭha chaviḥ iti gaṇaiḥ sa ādaram dṛśyamāṇaḥ puṇyam yāyāḥ tribhuvana guroḥ dhāma caṇḍeśvarasya
translated: you should go to the auspicious abode of Chandeshvara, the guru of the three worlds, respectfully seen by the ganas as the color on the neck of Shiva,

original: dhūtodyānaṃ kuvalayarajogandhibhir gandhavatyās toyakrīḍāniratayuvatisnānatiktair marudbhiḥ // //
analyzed: dhūta udyānam kuvalaya rajaḥ gandhibhiḥ gandhavatyāḥ toya krīḍā nirata yuvati snāna tiktaiḥ marudbhiḥ
translated: the garden of Gandhavati fragrant with the pollen of blue lotuses, with breezes bitter from the bathing of young women engaged in water sports.

original: apy anyasmiñ jaladhara mahākālam āsādya kāle sthātavyaṃ te nayanaviṣayaṃ yāvad abhyeti bhānuḥ /
analyzed: api anyasmin jaladhara mahā kālam āsādya kāle sthātavyam te nayana viṣayam yāvat abhyeti bhānuḥ
translated: O cloud, you should stay there for some time, until the sun comes into the range of sight, after reaching Mahakala in another season.

original: kurvan saṃdhyābalipaṭahatāṃ śūlinaḥ ślāghanīyām āmandrāṇāṃ phalam avikalaṃ lapsyase garjitānām // //
analyzed: kurvan saṃdhyā bali paṭaha tām śūlinaḥ ślāghanīyām āmandrāṇām phalam avikalam lapsyase garjitānām
translated: Making the praiseworthy sound of a kettle-drum for the oblation to Shiva at dusk, you will obtain the complete fruit of your deep thunderclaps.

original: pādanyāsakvaṇitaraśanās tatra līlāvadhūtai ratnacchāyākhacitavalibhiś cāmaraiḥ klāntahastāḥ /
analyzed: pāda nyāsa kvaṇita raśanāḥ tatra līlā avadhūtaiḥ ratna chāyā khacita valibhiḥ cāmaraiḥ klānta hastāḥ
translated: There, with their girdles jingling with the movement of their feet, their hands tired from the chowries with jeweled luster waving playfully,

original: veśyās tvatto nakhapadasukhān prāpya varṣāgrabindūn āmokṣyanti tvayi madhukaraśreṇidīrghān kaṭākṣān // //
analyzed: veśyāḥ tvattaḥ nakha pada sukhān prāpya varṣa agra bindūn āmokṣyanti tvayi madhukara śreṇi dīrghān kaṭākṣān
translated: The harlots, having received from you the first drops of rain, pleasant like nail-marks, will cast at you sidelong glances long like a line of bees.

original: paścād uccairbhujataruvanaṃ maṇḍalenābhilīnaḥ sāṃdhyaṃ tejaḥ pratinavajapāpuṣparaktaṃ dadhānaḥ /
analyzed: paścāt uccais bhuja taru vanam maṇḍalena abhilīnaḥ sāṃdhyam tejaḥ pratinava japā puṣpa raktam dadhānaḥ
translated: Afterwards, hidden by a circle of tall trees of your arms, bearing the evening glow reddened by the newly blossomed japā flowers,

original: nṛttārambhe hara paśupater ārdranāgājinecchāṃ śāntodvegastimitanayanaṃ dṛṣṭabhaktir bhavānyā // //
analyzed: nṛtta ārambhe hara paśupateḥ ārdra nāga ajina icchām śānta udvega stimita nayanam dṛṣṭa bhaktiḥ bhavānyā
translated: at the commencement of the dance, O Śiva, take away the desire for the wet elephant hide of Śiva, and be seen by Pārvatī with eyes still and free from anxiety, having seen your devotion.

original: gacchantīnāṃ ramaṇavasatiṃ yoṣitāṃ tatra naktaṃ ruddhāloke narapatipathe sūcibhedyais tamobhiḥ /
analyzed: gacchantīnām ramaṇa vasatim yoṣitām tatra naktam ruddha āloke narapati pathe sūci bhedyaiḥ tamobhiḥ
translated: When the women are going at night to the houses of their lovers on the king's road, where the darkness can be pierced by a needle,

original: saudāminyā kanakanikaṣasnigdhayā darśayorvīṃ toyotsargastanitamukharo mā sma bhūr viklavās tāḥ // //
analyzed: saudāminyā kanaka nikaṣa snigdhayā darśaya urvīm toya utsarga stanita mukharaḥ mā sma bhūḥ viklavāḥ tāḥ
translated: show them the sky with the lightning flash smooth like a golden mirror, but do not make a loud noise by letting fall rain, lest they be frightened.

original: tāṃ kasyāṃ cid bhavanavalabhau suptapārāvatāyāṃ nītvā rātriṃ ciravilasanāt khinnavidyutkalatraḥ /
analyzed: tām kasyām cit bhavana valabhau supta pārāvatāyām nītvā rātrim cira vilasanāt khinna vidyut kalatraḥ
translated: Having spent the night in some house with sleeping pigeons on the balcony, with your lightning wife tired from a long enjoyment,

original: dṛṣṭe sūrye punar api bhavān vāhayed adhvaśeṣaṃ mandāyante na khalu suhṛdām abhyupetārthakṛtyāḥ // //
analyzed: dṛṣṭe sūrye punar api bhavān vāhayet adhva śeṣam mandāyante na khalu suhṛdām abhyupeta artha kṛtyāḥ
translated: when the sun is seen, you should again carry on the remaining journey, for the tasks undertaken by friends do not slacken.

original: tasmin kāle nayanasalilaṃ yoṣitāṃ khaṇḍitānāṃ śāntiṃ neyaṃ praṇayibhir ato vartma bhānos tyajāśu /
analyzed: tasmin kāle nayana salilam yoṣitām khaṇḍitānām śāntim nā iyam praṇayibhiḥ atas vartma bhānoḥ tyaja āśu
translated: At that time, the tears from the eyes of the offended women will not be pacified by their lovers, so quickly leave the path of the sun.

original: prāleyāsraṃ kamalavadanāt so 'pi hartuṃ nalinyāḥ pratyāvṛttas tvayi kararudhi syād analpābhyasūyaḥ // //
analyzed: prāleya asram kamala vadanāt saḥ pi hartum nalinyāḥ pratyāvṛttaḥ tvayi kararudhi syāt analpa abhyasūyaḥ
translated: He, the sun, will return to take away the water of snow from the lotus face of the lily pond, but in you, O friend to the lotuses, he will be greatly despised.

original: gambhīrāyāḥ payasi saritaś cetasīva prasanne chāyātmāpi prakṛtisubhago lapsyate te praveśam /
analyzed: gambhīrāyāḥ payasi saritaḥ cetasi iva prasanne chāyā ātmā api prakṛti subhagaḥ lapsyate te praveśam
translated: In the clear water of the deep river, as if in a clear mind, your shadow-self will find entry.

original: tasmāt tasyāḥ kumudaviśadāny arhasi tvaṃ na dhairyān moghīkartuṃ caṭulaśapharodvartanaprekṣitāni // //
analyzed: tasmāt tasyāḥ kumuda viśadāni arhasi tvam na dhairyāt moghīkartum caṭula śaphara udvartana prekṣitāni
translated: Therefore, you should not, out of firmness, render futile her eyes, clear as lilies, which watch the playful darting about of the minnows.

original: tasyāḥ kiṃ cit karadhṛtam iva prāptavānīraśākhaṃ hṛtvā nīlaṃ salilavasanaṃ muktarodhonitambam /
analyzed: tasyāḥ kim cit kara dhṛtam iva prāptavā nīra śākham hṛtvā nīlam salila vasanam mukta rodhaḥ nitambam
translated: Having taken away her blue garment, the water, with the hips of the sandbanks released, and with the reeds for branches held a little in the hand,

original: prasthānaṃ te katham api sakhe lambamānasya bhāvi jñātāsvādaḥ pulinajaghanāṃ ko vihātuṃ samarthaḥ // //
analyzed: prasthānam te katham api sakhe lambamānasya bhāvi jñāta āsvādaḥ pulina jaghanām kaḥ vihātum samarthaḥ
translated: how, O friend, will your departure take place, hanging as you are? Who, having tasted it, is able to leave the hips of the sandbanks?

original: tvanniṣyandocchvasitavasudhāgandhasaṃparkapuṇyaḥ srotorandhradhvanitasubhagaṃ dantibhiḥ pīyamānaḥ /
analyzed: tvad nisyanda ucchvasita vasudhā gandha saṃparka puṇyaḥ srotaḥ randhra dhvanita subhagam dantibhiḥ pīyamānaḥ
translated: Blessed by the contact with the fragrance of the earth exhaled by your flow, drunk by the elephants with their trunks swaying gracefully,

original: nīcair vāsyaty upajigamiṣor devapūrvaṃ giriṃ te śīto vāyuḥ pariṇamayitā kānanodumbarāṇām // //
analyzed: nīcais vā asyati upajigamiṣoḥ deva pūrvam girim te śītaḥ vāyuḥ pariṇamayitā kānana udumbarāṇām
translated: The cool wind, which is about to go to the mountain which is worshipped by the gods, will carry you down low. It will ripen the wild figs in the forest.

original: tatra skandaṃ niyatavasatiṃ puṣpameghīkṛtātmā puṣpāsāraiḥ snapayatu bhavān vyomagaṅgājalārdraiḥ /
analyzed: tatra skandam niyata vasatim puṣpa meghīkṛta ātmā puṣpa āsāraiḥ snapayatu bhavān vyomagaṅgā jala ārdraiḥ
translated: There, you should bathe Skanda, who has made his abode there, with showers of flowers moistened by the water of the celestial Ganges.

original: rakṣāhetor navaśaśibhṛtā vāsavīnāṃ camūnām atyādityaṃ hutavahamukhe saṃbhṛtaṃ tadd hi tejaḥ // //
analyzed: rakṣā hetoḥ nava śaśi bhṛtā vāsavīnām camūnām ati ādityam hutavaha mukhe saṃbhṛtam tat hi tejaḥ
translated: For the sake of protection, the army of the Vasus, which holds the new moon, has collected that fiery energy in the mouth of the sacrificial fire, which is more radiant than the sun.

original: jyotirlekhāvalayi galitaṃ yasya barhaṃ bhavānī putraprītyā kuvalayapadaprāpi karṇe karoti /🔽dhautāpāṅgaṃ haraśaśirucā pāvakes taṃ mayūraṃ paścād adrigrahaṇagurubhir garjitair nartayethāḥ // //
analyzed: jyotiḥ lekhā valayi galitam yasya barham bhavānī putra prītyā kuvalaya pada prāpi karṇe karoti  dhauta apāṅgam hara śaśi rucā pāvakeḥ tam mayūram paścāt adri grahaṇa gurubhiḥ garjitaiḥ nartayethāḥ
translated: The peacock, whose peacock feathers have fallen from the circle of light rays, Bhavani places on her ear out of love for her son, reaching the level of a blue lotus.🔽After washing its eyes with the moon's nectar, you should make that peacock dance with your thunderclaps, which are heavy with the weight of the mountain you have seized.

original: ārādhyaivaṃ śaravaṇabhuvaṃ devam ullaṅghitādhvā siddhadvandvair jalakaṇabhayād vīṇibhir muktamārgaḥ /
analyzed: ārādhya evam śaravaṇa bhuvam devam ullaṅghita adhvā siddha dvandvaiḥ jala kaṇa bhayāt vīṇibhiḥ mukta mārgaḥ
translated: Having thus worshipped the god of the Sharavana grove, having crossed the path, with the pairs of Siddhas, who have abandoned their musical instruments out of fear of the water drops,

original: vyālambethāḥ surabhitanayālambhajāṃ mānayiṣyan srotomūrtyā bhuvi pariṇatāṃ rantidevasya kīrtim // //
analyzed: vyālambethāḥ surabhi tanaya ālambha jām mānayiṣyan srotaḥ mūrtyā bhuvi pariṇatām rantidevasya kīrtim
translated: you should hang down, honoring the fame of Rantideva, which has taken a bodily form in the stream, and which has come down to earth, out of love for the daughter of Surabhi.

original: tvayy ādātuṃ jalam avanate śārṅgiṇo varṇacaure tasyāḥ sindhoḥ pṛthum api tanuṃ dūrabhāvāt pravāham /🔽prekṣiṣyante gaganagatayo dūram āvarjya dṛṣṭīr ekaṃ muktāguṇam iva bhuvaḥ sthūlamadhyendranīlam // //
analyzed: tvayi ādātum jalam avanate śārṅgiṇaḥ varṇa caure tasyāḥ sindhoḥ pṛthum api tanum dūra bhāvāt pravāham  prekṣiṣyante gagana gatayaḥ dūram āvarjya dṛṣṭīḥ ekam muktā guṇam iva bhuvaḥ sthūla madhya indranīlam
translated: When you bend down to drink its water, the river will seem to you, O Krishna, to be very broad, for you will see its current from afar.🔽The birds flying in the sky will turn their eyes to see you, and will think that you are a large sapphire, a single pearl of the earth, in the middle of the broad river.

original: tām uttīrya vraja paricitabhrūlatāvibhramāṇāṃ pakṣmotkṣepād uparivilasatkṛṣṇaśāraprabhāṇām /
analyzed: tām uttīrya vraja paricita bhrū latā vibhramāṇām pakṣma utkṣepāt upari vilasat kṛṣṇa śāra prabhāṇām
translated: Having crossed it, go to the country of Brahmavarta, casting your shadow below it. There the brows of the women are well-known for their playful movements, and the lustre of their dark hair shines above them when their eyelashes are raised.

original: kundakṣepānugamadhukaraśrīmuṣām ātmabimbaṃ pātrīkurvan daśapuravadhūnetrakautūhalānām // //🔽brahmāvartaṃ janapadam adhaśchāyayā gāhamānaḥ kṣetraṃ kṣatrapradhanapiśunaṃ kauravaṃ tad bhajethāḥ /
analyzed: kunda kṣepa anuga madhukara śrī muṣām ātma bimbam pātrīkurvan daśa pura vadhū netra kautūhalānām  brahmāvartam janapadam adhas chāyayā gāhamānaḥ kṣetram kṣatra pradhana piśunam kauravam tat bhajethāḥ
translated: Stealing the beauty of the bees that follow the throwing of jasmine flowers, making yourself a vessel for the curiosity of the eyes of the women of Dashpura.

original: rājanyānāṃ śitaśaraśatair yatra gāṇḍīvadhanvā dhārāpātais tvam iva kamalāny abhyavarṣan mukhāni // //
analyzed: rājanyānām śita śara śataiḥ yatra gāṇḍīvadhanvā dhārā pātaiḥ tvam iva kamalāni abhyavarṣat mukhāni
translated: There you should visit the field of the Kauravas, which is notorious for the slaughter of the Kshatriyas, where the wielder of Gandiva, with hundreds of sharp arrows, showered the faces of the Kshatriyas like you with torrents of rain on lotuses.

original: hitvā hālām abhimatarasāṃ revatīlocanāṅkāṃ bandhuprītyā samaravimukho lāṅgalī yāḥ siṣeve /
analyzed: hitvā hālām abhimata rasām revatī locana aṅkām bandhu prītyā samara vimukhaḥ lāṅgalī yāḥ siṣeve
translated: Having abandoned the beloved drink of the hala plant, marked with the eyes of Revati, the ploughman, averse to battle out of affection for his kinsmen, served the women of the Yadava clan.

original: kṛtvā tāsām abhigamam apāṃ somya sārasvatīnām antaḥsvacchas tvam api bhavitā varṇamātreṇa kṛṣṇaḥ // //
analyzed: kṛtvā tāsām abhigamam apām somya sārasvatīnām antar svacchaḥ tvam api bhavitā varṇa mātreṇa kṛṣṇaḥ
translated: Having visited those waters of the Sarasvati, you too will become clear within, only black in color.

original: tasmād gaccher anukanakhalaṃ śailarājāvatīrṇāṃ jahnoḥ kanyāṃ sagaratanayasvargasopānapaṅktim /
analyzed: tasmāt gaccheḥ anukanakhalam śailarāja avatīrṇām jahnoḥ kanyām sagara tanaya svarga sopāna paṅktim
translated: Therefore, you should go to the daughter of Jahnu, who descended from the king of mountains along the Kanakhala, the stairway to heaven for the sons of Sagara.

original: gaurīvaktrabhrukuṭiracanāṃ yā vihasyeva phenaiḥ śambhoḥ keśagrahaṇam akarod indulagnormihastā // //
analyzed: gaurī vaktra bhrukuṭi racanām yā vihasya iva phenaiḥ śambhoḥ keśa grahaṇam akarot indu lagna ūrmi hastā
translated: She, with her waves serving as hands, as if laughed with foam at the arrangement of the frown on Shiva's forehead, which is like Gauri's face, and seized his hair, with the moon clinging to it.

original: tasyāḥ pātuṃ suragaja iva vyomni pūrvārdhalambī tvaṃ ced acchasphaṭikaviśadaṃ tarkayes tiryag ambhaḥ /
analyzed: tasyāḥ pātum sura gajaḥ iva vyomni pūrva ardha lambī tvam ced accha sphaṭika viśadam tarkayeḥ tiryak ambhaḥ
translated: If you, like an elephant of the gods, were to look obliquely at her water, clear like pure crystal, hanging down in the eastern sky,

original: saṃsarpantyā sapadi bhavataḥ srotasi cchāyayā sā syād asthānopanatayamunāsaṃgam evābhirāmā // //🔽āsīnānāṃ surabhitaśilaṃ nābhigandhair mṛgāṇāṃ tasyā eva prabhavam acalaṃ prāpya gauraṃ tuṣāraiḥ /
analyzed: saṃsarpantyā sapadi bhavataḥ srotasi chāyayā sā syāt a sthāna upanata yamunā saṃgam eva abhirāmā  āsīnānām surabhita śilam nābhi gandhaiḥ mṛgāṇām tasyāḥ eva prabhavam acalam prāpya gauram tuṣāraiḥ
translated: her shadow would immediately glide into your current, and she would be as delightful as the confluence with Yamuna, which comes to her naturally.🔽Sitting on her peak, which is white with snow, the source of that river, fragrant with the scent of the bellies of deer,

original: vakṣyasy adhvaśramavinayane tasya śṛṅge niṣaṇṇaḥ śobhāṃ ramyāṃ trinayanavṛṣotkhātapaṅkopameyām // //
analyzed: vakṣyasi adhva śrama vinayane tasya śṛṅge niṣaṇṇaḥ śobhām ramyām trinayana vṛṣa utkhāta paṅka upameyām
translated: you will tell of its beauty, which can be compared to the mud churned up by the bull of the three-eyed Shiva, while resting there to relieve the fatigue of the journey.

original: taṃ ced vāyau sarati saralaskandhasaṃghaṭṭajanmā bādhetolkākṣapitacamarīvālabhāro davāgniḥ /
analyzed: tam ced vāyau sarati sarala skandha saṃghaṭṭa janmā bādheta ulkā kṣapita camarī vāla bhāraḥ dava agniḥ
translated: If a forest fire, born from the collision of Sarala trees, should threaten him, carrying with it the burden of Chamari deer driven away by the flames,

original: arhasy enaṃ śamayitum alaṃ vāridhārāsahasrair āpannārtipraśamanaphalāḥ saṃpado hy uttamānām // //
analyzed: arhasi enam śamayitum alam vāri dhārā sahasraiḥ āpanna ārti praśamana phalāḥ saṃpadaḥ hi uttamānām
translated: you are well able to extinguish it with thousands of streams of water, for the wealth of the great bears fruit in the relief of those in distress.

original: ye tvāṃ muktadhvanim asahanāḥ kāyabhaṅgāya tasmin darpotsekād upari śarabhā laṅghayiṣyanty alaṅghyam /
analyzed: ye tvām mukta dhvanim asahanāḥ kāya bhaṅgāya tasmin darpa utsekāt upari śarabhāḥ laṅghayiṣyanti a laṅghyam
translated: Those Sharabhas, unable to bear your trumpeting, out of pride and arrogance, will try to leap over you, the uncrossable, to their own destruction.

original: tān kurvīthās tumulakarakāvṛṣṭihāsāvakīrṇān ke vā na syuḥ paribhavapadaṃ niṣphalārambhayatnāḥ // //
analyzed: tān kurvīthāḥ tumula karaka āvṛṣṭi hāsa avakīrṇān ke vā na syuḥ paribhava padam niṣphala ārambha yatnāḥ
translated: You should scatter them with a laugh accompanied by a shower of hailstones. Who would not be objects of contempt, their efforts at action fruitless?

original: tatra vyaktaṃ dṛṣadi caraṇanyāsam ardhendumauleḥ śaśvat siddhair upahṛtabaliṃ bhaktinamraḥ parīyāḥ /
analyzed: tatra vyaktam dṛṣadi caraṇa nyāsam ardha indumauleḥ śaśvat siddhaiḥ upahṛta balim bhakti namraḥ parīyāḥ
translated: There, with devotion and humility, you should circumambulate the footprint of the moon-crested Shiva on the rock, to which offerings are constantly brought by the Siddhas,

original: yasmin dṛṣṭe karaṇavigamād ūrdhvam uddhūtapāpāḥ kalpante 'sya sthiragaṇapadaprāptaye śraddadhānāḥ // //
analyzed: yasmin dṛṣṭe karaṇa vigamāt ūrdhvam uddhūta pāpāḥ kalpante sthira gaṇa pada prāptaye śraddadhānāḥ
translated: by beholding which, the faithful, their sins shaken off by the separation from the senses after death, are fit for attaining the firm rank of his attendants.

original: śabdāyante madhuram anilaiḥ kīcakāḥ pūryamāṇāḥ saṃraktābhis tripuravijayo gīyate kiṃnarībhiḥ /
analyzed: śabdāyante madhuram anilaiḥ kīcakāḥ pūryamāṇāḥ saṃraktābhiḥ tripuravijayaḥ gīyate kiṃnarībhiḥ
translated: The reeds, being filled with wind, sound sweetly, and the Kinnara women sing the victory over the three cities in melodious voices.

original: nirhrādī te muraja iva cet kandarāsu dhvaniḥ syāt saṃgītārtho nanu paśupates tatra bhāvī samastaḥ // //
analyzed: nirhrādī te murajaḥ iva ced kandarāsu dhvaniḥ syāt saṃgīta arthaḥ nanu paśupateḥ tatra bhāvī samastaḥ
translated: If your voice, deep as a war-drum, should resound in the mountain caves, then all the music of Shiva will be there.

original: prāleyādrer upataṭam atikramya tāṃs tān viśeṣān haṃsadvāraṃ bhṛgupatiyaśovartma yat krauñcarandhram /
analyzed: prāleya adreḥ upataṭam atikramya tān tān viśeṣān haṃsadvāram bhṛgupati yaśaḥ vartma yat krauñcarandhram
translated: Passing beyond those various places on the slope of the snowy mountain, you should go to Hamsadvāra, the path of fame of the lord of Bhṛgu, which is Krauñcharandhra.

original: tenodīcīṃ diśam abhisares tiryagāyāmaśobhī śyāmaḥ pādo baliniyamanābhyudyatasyeva viṣṇoḥ // //
analyzed: tena udīcīm diśam abhisareḥ tiryak āyāma śobhī śyāmaḥ pādaḥ bali niyamana abhyudyatasya iva viṣṇoḥ
translated: With its beauty extending sideways, you should go to the northern direction, like the dark foot of Vishnu, ready to subdue the powerful demons.

original: gatvā cordhvaṃ daśamukhabhujocchvāsitaprasthasaṃdheḥ kailāsasya tridaśavanitādarpaṇasyātithiḥ syāḥ /🔽śṛṅgocchrāyaiḥ kumudaviśadair yo vitatya sthitaḥ khaṃ rāśībhūtaḥ pratiniśam iva tryambakasyāṭṭahāsaḥ // //🔽utpaśyāmi tvayi taṭagate snigdhabhinnāñjanābhe sadyaḥkṛttadviradadaśanacchedagaurasya tasya /
analyzed: gatvā ca ūrdhvam daśa mukha bhuja ucchvāsita prastha saṃdheḥ kailāsasya tridaśa vanitā darpaṇasya atithiḥ syāḥ  śṛṅga ucchrāyaiḥ kumuda viśadaiḥ yaḥ vitatya sthitaḥ kham rāśībhūtaḥ pratiniśam iva tryambakasya aṭṭahāsaḥ  utpaśyāmi tvayi taṭa gate snigdha bhinna añjana ābhe sadyas kṛtta dvirada daśana cheda gaurasya tasya
translated: And going upwards, you should be a guest of Kailāsa, the mountain whose joints are exhaled by the arms of Rāvaṇa, the mirror of the celestial women.🔽It stands with its peaks white like lilies, extending to the sky, like a mass of laughter of Śiva, appearing every night.🔽When you stand on its slope, dark like well-ground collyrium, I see that mountain's playfulness will be seen with motionless eyes,

original: līlām adreḥ stimitanayanaprekṣaṇīyāṃ bhavitrīm aṃsanyaste sati halabhṛto mecake vāsasīva // //
analyzed: līlām adreḥ stimita nayana prekṣaṇīyām bhavitrīm aṃsa nyaste sati halabhṛtaḥ mecake vāsasi iva
translated: like the dark garments of the plough-bearer placed on the shoulder, when you place them there.

original: hitvā nīlaṃ bhujagavalayaṃ śambhunā dattahastā krīḍāśaile yadi ca viharet pādacāreṇa gaurī /
analyzed: hitvā nīlam bhujaga valayam śambhunā datta hastā krīḍā śaile yadi ca viharet pāda cāreṇa gaurī
translated: If Gauri were to leave the blue serpent-bracelets and walk on foot on the pleasure-hill, given by Shambhu,

original: bhaṅgībhaktyā viracitavapuḥ stambhitāntarjalo 'syāḥ sopānatvaṃ kuru sukhapadasparśam ārohaṇeṣu // //
analyzed: bhaṅgī bhaktyā viracita vapuḥ stambhita antar jalaḥ syāḥ sopāna tvam kuru sukha pada sparśam ārohaṇeṣu
translated: may you, O friend, become a staircase for her to climb, with your body formed of bending trees, and the water within you held back.

original: tatrāvaśyaṃ janitasalilodgāram antaḥpraveśān neṣyanti tvāṃ surayuvatayo yantradhārāgṛhatvam /
analyzed: tatra avaśyam janita salila udgāram antar praveśāt neṣyanti tvām sura yuvatayaḥ yantra dhārā gṛha tvam
translated: There, the young celestial women, bringing forth water from within, will certainly make you serve as a shower-bath.

original: tābhyo mokṣas tava yadi sakhe gharmalabdhasya na syāt krīḍālolāḥ śravaṇaparuṣair garjitair bhāyayes tāḥ // //
analyzed: tābhyaḥ mokṣaḥ tava yadi sakhe gharma labdhasya na syāt krīḍā lolāḥ śravaṇa paruṣaiḥ garjitaiḥ bhāyayeḥ tāḥ
translated: If, O friend, you do not get relief from the heat, you should frighten them with your playful roars harsh to the ears.

original: hemāmbhojaprasavi salilaṃ mānasasyādadānaḥ kurvan kāmāt kṣaṇamukhapaṭaprītim airāvaṇasya /
analyzed: hema ambhoja prasavi salilam mānasasya ādadānaḥ kurvan kāmāt kṣaṇa mukha paṭa prītim airāvaṇasya
translated: Taking the water of the Manasa lake, producing golden lotuses, giving momentary pleasure to the face-cloth of Airavata out of love,

original: dhunvan vātaiḥ sajalapṛṣataiḥ kalpavṛkṣāṃśukāni cchāyābhinnaḥ sphaṭikaviśadaṃ nirviśeḥ paravataṃ tam // //
analyzed: dhunvan vātaiḥ sa jala pṛṣataiḥ kalpavṛkṣa aṃśukāni chāyā bhinnaḥ sphaṭika viśadam nirviśeḥ paravatam tam
translated: shaking the garments of the wish-fulfilling trees with breezes wet with water, you should enter that other mountain, clear as crystal, with its shadow indistinguishable.

original: tasyotsaṅge praṇayina iva srastagaṅgādugūlāṃ na tvaṃ dṛṣṭvā na punar alakāṃ jñāsyase kāmacārin /
analyzed: tasya utsaṅge praṇayinaḥ iva srasta gaṅgā dugūlām na tvam dṛṣṭvā na punar alakām jñāsyase kāma cārin
translated: O one who moves at will, having seen that mountain with the Ganga's waters falling on it like a beloved woman, you will not recognize Alakā again.

original: yā vaḥ kāle vahati salilodgāram uccairvimānā muktājālagrathitam alakaṃ kāminīvābhravṛndam // //
analyzed: yā vaḥ kāle vahati salila udgāram uccais vimānā muktā jāla grathitam alakam kāminī iva abhra vṛndam
translated: Which carries your rain showers in time, high in the sky, like a bevy of damsels with hair entwined with pearl strings.

original: vidyutvantaṃ lalitavanitāḥ sendracāpaṃ sacitrāḥ saṃgītāya prahatamurajāḥ snigdhagambhīraghoṣam /
analyzed: vidyutvantam lalita vanitāḥ sa indracāpam sa citrāḥ saṃgītāya prahata murajāḥ snigdha gambhīra ghoṣam
translated: The women, charming like young ladies, with rainbows, and with colorful drums beaten for music, with deep and sweet sounds,

original: antastoyaṃ maṇimayabhuvas tuṅgam abhraṃlihāgrāḥ prāsādās tvāṃ tulayitum alaṃ yatra tais tair viśeṣaiḥ // //
analyzed: antar toyam maṇi maya bhuvaḥ tuṅgam abhraṃliha agrāḥ prāsādāḥ tvām tulayitum alam yatra taiḥ taiḥ viśeṣaiḥ
translated: The mansions, with water inside, with floors made of jewels, tall, with tops touching the clouds, are able to match you with those special qualities.

original: haste līlākamalam alakaṃ bālakundānuviddhaṃ nītā rodhraprasavarajasā pāṇḍutām ānanaśrīḥ /
analyzed: haste līlā kamalam alakam bāla kunda anuviddham nītā rodhra prasava rajasā pāṇḍu tām ānana śrīḥ
translated: In her hand, a playful lotus, her hair entwined with jasmine flowers, the beauty of her face turned pale with the pollen of rhododendron flowers,

original: cūḍāpāśe navakuravakaṃ cāru karṇe śirīṣaṃ sīmante ca tvadupagamajaṃ yatra nīpaṃ vadhūnām // //
analyzed: cūḍā pāśe nava kuravakam cāru karṇe śirīṣam sīmante ca tvad upagama jam yatra nīpam vadhūnām
translated: In the braid, a fresh kuruvaka flower, a beautiful sirisha flower in her ear, and in her parting, a neem flower born from your arrival, of the young brides.

original: yasyāṃ yakṣāḥ sitamaṇimayāny etya harmyasthalāni jyotiśchāyākusumaracanāny uttamastrīsahāyāḥ /
analyzed: yasyām yakṣāḥ sita maṇi mayāni etya harmya sthalāni jyotiḥ chāyā kusuma racanāni uttama strī sahāyāḥ
translated: In which the Yakshas, coming to the jeweled terraces, accompanied by the best of women,

original: āsevante madhu ratiphalaṃ kalpavṛkṣaprasūtaṃ tvadgambhīradhvaniṣu śanakaiḥ puṣkareṣv āhateṣu // //
analyzed: āsevante madhu rati phalam kalpavṛkṣa prasūtam tvad gambhīra dhvaniṣu śanakais puṣkareṣu āhateṣu
translated: Enjoy the honey fruit of love, born from the wish-fulfilling tree, when your deep sounds are slowly beaten on the drums.

original: yatra strīṇāṃ priyatamabhujāliṅganocchvāsitānām aṅgaglāniṃ suratajanitāṃ tantujālāvalambāḥ /🔽tvatsaṃrodhāpagamaviśadaiś cotitāś candrapādair vyālumpanti sphuṭajalalavasyandinaś candrakāntāḥ // //
analyzed: yatra strīṇām priyatama bhuja āliṅgana ucchvāsitānām aṅga glānim surata janitām tantu jāla avalambāḥ  tvad saṃrodha apagama viśadaiḥ cotitāḥ candra pādaiḥ vyālumpanti sphuṭa jala lava syandinaḥ candrakāntāḥ
translated: Where the moonstones, refreshed by the clear rays of the moon, which have dispelled the obstruction caused by you, and dripping with drops of clear water, remove the languor of the limbs of the women, caused by love-making, which was relieved by the sighs of embracing their beloveds.

original: netrā nītāḥ satatagatinā yad vimānāgrabhūmīr ālekhyānāṃ navajalakaṇair doṣam utpādya sadyaḥ /
analyzed: netrā nītāḥ satatagatinā yat vimāna agra bhūmīḥ ālekhyānām nava jala kaṇaiḥ doṣam utpādya sadyas
translated: Where the eyes of the celestial women, which were led to the highest point of the celestial cars, having immediately produced a fault in the paintings with fresh water-drops,

original: śaṅkāspṛṣṭā iva jalamucas tvādṛśā yatra jālair dhūmodgārānukṛtinipuṇaṃ jarjarā niṣpatanti // //
analyzed: śaṅkā spṛṣṭāḥ iva jalamucaḥ tvādṛśāḥ yatra jālaiḥ dhūma udgāra anukṛti nipuṇam jarjarāḥ niṣpatanti
translated: are falling shattered through the nets, as if touched with suspicion, like the clouds, skilled in imitating the emission of smoke, like you.

original: nīvībandhocchvasanaśithilaṃ yatra yakṣāṅganānāṃ vāsaḥ kāmād anibhṛtakareṣv ākṣipatsu priyeṣu /
analyzed: nīvī bandha ucchvasana śithilam yatra yakṣa aṅganānām vāsaḥ kāmāt a nibhṛta kareṣu ākṣipatsu priyeṣu
translated: Where, when the beloveds, out of love, pull down the garments of the Yaksha women, loosened by the knot of the waist-band, with their hands moving unsteadily,

original: arcistuṅgān abhimukham api prāpya ratnapradīpān hrīmūḍhānāṃ bhavati viphalapreraṇaś cūrṇamuṣṭiḥ // //
analyzed: arciḥ tuṅgān abhimukham api prāpya ratna pradīpān hrī mūḍhānām bhavati viphala preraṇaḥ cūrṇa muṣṭiḥ
translated: the handful of powder, though reaching the tall flames of the jewel-lamps, becomes uselessly scattered, out of shame and confusion, of those who are slow.

original: gatyutkampād alakapatitair yatra mandārapuṣpaiḥ kḷptacchedyaiḥ kanakakamalaiḥ karṇavibhraṃśibhiś ca /
analyzed: gati utkampāt alaka patitaiḥ yatra mandāra puṣpaiḥ kḷpta chedyaiḥ kanaka kamalaiḥ karṇa vibhraṃśibhiḥ ca
translated: Where, the mandara flowers fallen from the hair due to the agitation of movement, and the golden lotuses dislodged from the ears,

original: muktālagnastanaparimalaiś chinnasūtraiś ca hārair naiśo mārgaḥ savitur udaye sūcyate kāminīnām // //
analyzed: muktā lagna stana parimalaiḥ chinna sūtraiḥ ca hāraiḥ naiśaḥ mārgaḥ savituḥ udaye sūcyate kāminīnām
translated: The path of love-making of the young women is indicated by the broken pearl necklaces and the fallen garlands of flowers from their breasts at sunrise.

original: matvā devaṃ dhanapatisakhaṃ yatra sākṣād vasantaṃ prāyaś cāpaṃ na vahati bhayān manmathaḥ ṣaṭpadajyam /
analyzed: matvā devam dhanapati sakham yatra sākṣāt vasantam prāyas cāpam na vahati bhayāt manmathaḥ ṣaṭpada jyam
translated: Where the god of love, the friend of Kubera, resides in person, and the god of love, out of fear, does not usually carry his bow with a string of bees.

original: sabhrūbhaṅgaprahitanayanaiḥ kāmilakṣyeṣv amoghais tasyārambhaś caturavanitāvibhramair eva siddhaḥ // //
analyzed: sa bhrū bhaṅga prahita nayanaiḥ kāmi lakṣyeṣu amoghaiḥ tasya ārambhaḥ catura vanitā vibhramaiḥ eva siddhaḥ
translated: His undertaking is accomplished by the charming gestures of the clever women themselves, with their unfailing glances shot with arched eyebrows at the targets of love.

original: tatrāgāraṃ dhanapatigṛhān uttareṇāsmadīyaṃ dūrāl lakṣyaṃ tad amaradhanuś cāruṇā toraṇena /
analyzed: tatra āgāram dhanapati gṛhān uttareṇa asmadīyam dūrāt lakṣyam tat amara dhanuḥ cāruṇā toraṇena
translated: There, to the north of Kubera's house, our house can be seen from afar with its beautiful archway, lovely like the bow of the gods.

original: yasyopānte kṛtakatanayaḥ kāntayā vardhito me hastaprāpyastavakanamito bālamandāravṛkṣaḥ // //
analyzed: yasya upānte kṛtaka tanayaḥ kāntayā vardhitaḥ me hasta prāpya stavaka namitaḥ bāla mandāra vṛkṣaḥ
translated: Near it, my beloved's son, brought up by his nurse, is seen bending down with his hand to the young coral tree.

original: vāpī cāsmin marakataśilābaddhasopānamārgā haimaiḥ syūtā kamalamukulaiḥ snigdhavaiḍūryanālaiḥ /
analyzed: vāpī ca asmin marakata śilā baddha sopāna mārgā haimaiḥ syūtā kamala mukulaiḥ snigdha vaiḍūrya nālaiḥ
translated: In it there is a tank with steps leading down to it made of emerald slabs, and covered with golden lotuses with glossy beryl stalks.

original: yasyās toye kṛtavasatayo mānasaṃ saṃnikṛṣṭaṃ na dhyāsyanti vyapagataśucas tvām api prekṣya haṃsāḥ // //
analyzed: yasyāḥ toye kṛta vasatayaḥ mānasam saṃnikṛṣṭam na dhyāsyanti vyapagata śucaḥ tvām api prekṣya haṃsāḥ
translated: The swans, having made their abode in its water, will not think of you, their minds being attracted to it, even though they are free from grief on seeing you.

original: yasyās tīre nicitaśikharaḥ peśalair indranīlaiḥ krīḍāśailaḥ kanakakadalīveṣṭanaprekṣaṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: yasyāḥ tīre nicita śikharaḥ peśalaiḥ indranīlaiḥ krīḍā śailaḥ kanakakadalī veṣṭana prekṣaṇīyaḥ
translated: On the bank of which is a pleasure hill with its peak covered with beautiful sapphires, looking like a golden plantain grove,

original: madgehinyāḥ priya iti sakhe cetasā kātareṇa prekṣyopāntasphuritataḍitaṃ tvāṃ tam eva smarāmi // //
analyzed: mad gehinyāḥ priyaḥ iti sakhe cetasā kātareṇa prekṣya upānta sphurita taḍitam tvām tam eva smarāmi
translated: I remember you, my friend, with a trembling heart, thinking that you are dear to my wife, seeing you with lightning flashing around you.

original: raktāśokaś calakisalayaḥ kesaraś cātra kāntaḥ pratyāsannau kuravakavṛter mādhavīmaṇḍapasya /
analyzed: rakta aśokaḥ cala kisalayaḥ kesaraḥ ca atra kāntaḥ pratyāsannau kuravaka vṛteḥ mādhavī maṇḍapasya
translated: Here, the red Ashoka tree with its tender sprouts moving, and the beautiful Kesara tree, are near the Madhavi bower surrounded by Kurabaka plants.

original: ekaḥ sakhyās tava saha mayā vāmapādābhilāṣī kāṅkṣaty anyo vadanamadirāṃ dohadacchadmanāsyāḥ // //
analyzed: ekaḥ sakhyāḥ tava saha mayā vāma pāda abhilāṣī kāṅkṣati anyaḥ vadana madirām dohada chadmanā asyāḥ
translated: One of them, desiring the left foot of your friend, longs for the wine of her mouth under the pretext of a craving.

original: tanmadhye ca sphaṭikaphalakā kāñcanī vāsayaṣṭir mūle naddhā maṇibhir anatiprauḍhavaṃśaprakāśaiḥ /
analyzed: tad madhye ca sphaṭika phalakā kāñcanī vāsayaṣṭiḥ mūle naddhā maṇibhiḥ an ati prauḍha vaṃśa prakāśaiḥ
translated: In the middle of it is a golden bedstead with crystal panels, fastened at the base with jewels shining like very young bamboo,

original: tālaiḥ śiñjadvalayasubhagair nartitaḥ kāntayā me yām adhyāste divasavigame nīlakaṇṭhaḥ suhṛd vaḥ // //
analyzed: tālaiḥ śiñjat valaya subhagaiḥ nartitaḥ kāntayā me yām adhyāste divasa vigame nīlakaṇṭhaḥ suhṛd vaḥ
translated: on which my beloved dances with me, with her beautiful bracelets jingling, at the end of the day, where the blue-throated one, your friend, resides.

original: ebhiḥ sādho hṛdayanihitair lakṣaṇair lakṣaṇīyaṃ dvāropānte likhitavapuṣau śaṅkhapadmau ca dṛṣṭvā /
analyzed: ebhiḥ sādho hṛdaya nihitaiḥ lakṣaṇaiḥ lakṣaṇīyam dvāra upānte likhita vapuṣau śaṅkha padmau ca dṛṣṭvā
translated: O good man, having recognized her by these signs placed in the heart, and seeing the images of Shankara and Lakshmi painted near the door,

original: kṣāmacchāyaṃ bhavanam adhunā madviyogena nūnaṃ sūryāpāye na khalu kamalaṃ puṣyati svām abhikhyām // //
analyzed: kṣāma chāyam bhavanam adhunā mad viyogena nūnam sūrya apāye na khalu kamalam puṣyati svām abhikhyām
translated: Now, by my absence, the house has surely become pale-hued; at the setting of the sun, a lotus does not maintain its beauty.

original: gatvā sadyaḥ kalabhatanutāṃ śīghrasaṃpātahetoḥ krīḍāśaile prathamakathite ramyasānau niṣaṇṇaḥ /🔽arhasy antarbhavanapatitāṃ kartum alpālpabhāsaṃ khadyotālīvilasitanibhāṃ vidyudunmeṣadṛṣṭim // //
analyzed: gatvā sadyas kalabha tanu tām śīghra saṃpāta hetoḥ krīḍā śaile prathama kathite ramya sānau niṣaṇṇaḥ  arhasi antar bhavana patitām kartum alpa alpa bhāsam khadyota ālī vilasita nibhām vidyut unmeṣa dṛṣṭim
translated: Having immediately assumed the form of a young elephant for the sake of swift descent, seated on the delightful peak of the play-mountain mentioned before,🔽you should make the lightning, with its eyes seen for a moment, pale in its luster, like a row of fireflies fallen into the inner chamber of a house.

original: tanvī śyāmā śikharadaśanā pakvabimbādharauṣṭhī madhye kṣāmā cakitahariṇaprekṣaṇī nimnanābhiḥ /🔽śroṇībhārād alasagamanā stokanamrā stanābhyāṃ yā tatra syād yuvativiṣaye sṛṣṭir ādyeva dhātuḥ // //🔽tāṃ jānīyāḥ parimitakathāṃ jīvitaṃ me dvitīyaṃ dūrībhūte mayi sahacare cakravākīm ivaikām /
analyzed: tanvī śyāmā śikhara daśanā pakva bimba adhara oṣṭhī madhye kṣāmā cakita hariṇa prekṣaṇī nimna nābhiḥ  śroṇī bhārāt alasa gamanā stoka namrā stanābhyām yā tatra syāt yuvati viṣaye sṛṣṭiḥ ādyā iva dhātuḥ  tām jānīyāḥ parimita kathām jīvitam me dvitīyam dūrībhūte mayi sahacare cakravākīm iva ekām
translated: Slender, dark, with pointed teeth, lips like ripe bimba fruit, thin in the middle, with eyes like a startled deer, with a navel-depression,🔽slow in movement due to the weight of her hips, slightly bent due to her breasts - she who is like the first creation of the Creator in the realm of young women there.🔽You should know her, with limited speech, my second life, like a solitary female chakravaka bird when her mate is far away.

original: gāḍhotkaṇṭhāguruṣu divaseṣv eṣu gacchatsu bālāṃ jātāṃ manye śiśiramathitāṃ padminīṃ vānyarūpām // //
analyzed: gāḍha utkaṇṭhā guruṣu divaseṣu eṣu gacchatsu bālām jātām manye śiśira mathitām padminīm vā anya rūpām
translated: As these days pass, heavy with deep longing, I think of the young girl, changed like a lotus crushed by frost.

original: nūnaṃ tasyāḥ prabalaruditocchūnanetraṃ bahūnāṃ niḥśvāsānām aśiśiratayā bhinnavarṇādharauṣṭham /🔽hastanyastaṃ mukham asakalavyakti lambālakatvād indor dainyaṃ tvadupasaraṇakliṣṭakānter bibharti // //
analyzed: nūnam tasyāḥ prabala rudita ucchūna netram bahūnām niḥśvāsānām aśiśira tayā bhinna varṇa adhara oṣṭham  hasta nyastam mukham asakala vyakti lamba alaka tvāt indoḥ dainyam tvad upasaraṇa kliṣṭa kānteḥ bibharti
translated: Surely, her face, with eyes swollen from intense weeping, and lips cracked by the hot breath of many sighs,🔽resting on her hand, has the pallor of the moon, its spots indistinct, when it is eclipsed by Rāhu and waned by its approach to you.

original: āloke te nipatati purā sā balivyākulā vā matsādṛśyaṃ virahatanu vā bhāvagamyaṃ likhantī /
analyzed: āloke te nipatati purā sā bali vyākulā vā mad sādṛśyam viraha tanu vā bhāva gamyam likhantī
translated: When your light falls on her, she may be busy with her worship, or writing something about me, her slender form, or the pain of separation, that can be understood only by her heart.

original: pṛcchantī vā madhuravacanāṃ śārikāṃ pañjarasthāṃ kac cid bhartuḥ smarasi nibhṛte tvaṃ hi tasya priyeti // //
analyzed: pṛcchantī vā madhura vacanām śārikām pañjara sthām kad cit bhartuḥ smarasi nibhṛte tvam hi tasya priyā iti
translated: Or she may be asking the sweet-voiced mynah bird in its cage, O discreet one, do you remember my husband? For you are his beloved.

original: utsaṅge vā malinavasane somya nikṣipya vīṇāṃ madgotrāṅkaṃ viracitapadaṃ geyam udgātukāmā /
analyzed: utsaṅge vā malina vasane somya nikṣipya vīṇām mad gotra aṅkam viracita padam geyam udgātu kāmā
translated: Or, dear one, placing the lute on her soiled garment, she may be about to sing a song composed by me, with my name in it.

original: tantrīr ārdrā nayanasalilaiḥ sārayitvā kathaṃ cid bhūyo bhūyaḥ svayam api kṛtāṃ mūrcchanāṃ vismarantī // //
analyzed: tantrīḥ ārdrāḥ nayana salilaiḥ sārayitvā katham cit bhūyas bhūyas svayam api kṛtām mūrcchanām vismarantī
translated: Having somehow moistened the strings with the tears from her eyes, she may be repeatedly forgetting the melody she herself composed.

original: śeṣān māsān gamanadivasaprastutasyāvadher vā vinyasyantī bhuvi gaṇanayā dehalīdattapuṣpaiḥ /
analyzed: śeṣān māsān gamana divasa prastutasya avadheḥ vā vinyasyantī bhuvi gaṇanayā dehalī datta puṣpaiḥ
translated: Or she may be passing the remaining months of the year begun on the day of your departure, counting them on the ground with flowers placed at the threshold.

original: saṃyogaṃ vā hṛdayanihitārambham āsvādayantī prāyeṇaite ramaṇaviraheṣv aṅganānāṃ vinodāḥ // //
analyzed: saṃyogam vā hṛdaya nihita ārambham āsvādayantī prāyeṇa ete ramaṇa viraheṣu aṅganānām vinodāḥ
translated: Or, perhaps, she is enjoying the union of her heart with the thought of me. These are generally the diversions of women when separated from their lovers.

original: ādye baddhā virahadivase yā śikhā dāma hitvā śāpasyānte vigalitaśucā yā mayonmocanīyā /
analyzed: ādye baddhā viraha divase yā śikhā dāma hitvā śāpasya ante vigalita śucā yā mayā unmocanīyā
translated: On the first day of our separation, I had tied her hair in a braid, leaving off her garland, which she will have to untie herself when the curse is over and her sorrow gone.

original: sparśakliṣṭām ayamitanakhenāsakṛt sārayantīṃ gaṇḍābhogāt kaṭhinaviṣamād ekaveṇīṃ kareṇa // //🔽savyāpārām ahani na tathā khedayed viprayogaḥ śaṅke rātrau gurutaraśucaṃ nirvinodāṃ sakhīṃ te /
analyzed: sparśa kliṣṭām ayamita nakhena asakṛt sārayantīm gaṇḍa ābhogāt kaṭhina viṣamāt eka veṇīm kareṇa  sa vyāpārām ahani na tathā khedayet viprayogaḥ śaṅke rātrau gurutara śucam nirvinodām sakhīm te
translated: With her hand, she will be constantly rubbing against her cheek, which is rough and hard, the single braid of hair that is painful to the touch, and which I have tied with my nails.🔽I fear that separation will not trouble her so much by day, when she is busy, but at night, when she has no diversions, her sorrow will be greater.

original: matsaṃdeśaiḥ sukhayitum ataḥ paśya sādhvīṃ niśīthe tām unnidrām avaniśayanāsannavātāyanasthaḥ // //
analyzed: mad saṃdeśaiḥ sukhayitum atas paśya sādhvīm niśīthe tām unnidrām avani śayana āsanna vātāyana sthaḥ
translated: Therefore, at midnight, you should look at your virtuous friend, who will be sleepless, standing in the window near her bed, to comfort her with my messages.

original: ādhikṣāmāṃ virahaśayane saṃnikīrṇaikapārśvāṃ prācīmūle tanum iva kalāmātraśeṣāṃ himāṃśoḥ /
analyzed: ādhi kṣāmām viraha śayane saṃnikīrṇa eka pārśvām prācīmūle tanum iva kalā mātra śeṣām himāṃśoḥ
translated: Emaciated by separation, lying on a bed of separation, with one cheek resting on the ground, like the moon at dawn, with only a digit remaining.

original: matsaṃyogaḥ katham upanamet svapnajo 'pīti nidrām ākāṅkṣantīṃ nayanasalilotpīḍaruddhāvakāśām // //
analyzed: mad saṃyogaḥ katham upanamet svapna jaḥ pi iti nidrām ākāṅkṣantīm nayana salila utpīḍa ruddha avakāśām
translated: Longing for sleep, thinking, How can I have even a dream union with him? with her eyes closed, her face covered with tears.

original: niḥśvāsenādharakisalayakleśinā vikṣipantīṃ śuddhasnānāt paruṣamalakaṃ nūnam āgaṇḍalambam /
analyzed: niḥśvāsena adhara kisalaya kleśinā vikṣipantīm śuddha snānāt paruṣam alakam nūnam ā gaṇḍa lambam
translated: She is shaking off the rough hair hanging down to her cheeks, which is dishevelled by the exertion of the lower lip in sighing, and which is rough from the bath.

original: nītā rātriḥ kṣaṇa iva mayā sārdham icchāratair yā tām evoṣṇair virahaśayaneṣv asrubhir yāpayantīm // //
analyzed: nītā rātriḥ kṣaṇaḥ iva mayā sārdham icchā rataiḥ yā tām evā uṣṇaiḥ viraha śayaneṣu asrubhiḥ yāpayantīm
translated: The night has been spent by me with her in love-sports as if it were a moment, but she is now passing it with hot tears on her couch of separation.

original: pādān indor amṛtaśiśirāñjālamārgapraviṣṭān pūrvaprītyā gatam abhimukhaṃ saṃnivṛttaṃ tathaiva /
analyzed: pādān indoḥ amṛta śiśirān jāla mārga praviṣṭān pūrva prītyā gatam abhimukham saṃnivṛttam tathā eva
translated: The eyes of the moon, cool with nectar, have entered the path of the net, and have turned back just as they had come, out of former affection.

original: cakṣuḥ khedāt sajalagurubhiḥ pakṣmabhiś chādayantīṃ sābhre 'hnīva sthalakamalinīṃ na prabuddhāṃ na suptām // //
analyzed: cakṣuḥ khedāt sa jala gurubhiḥ pakṣmabhiḥ chādayantīm sa abhre hni iva sthala kamalinīm na prabuddhām na suptām
translated: She is covering them with her eyelashes, heavy with water, out of weariness, like a land-lotus on a cloudy day, neither awake nor asleep.

original: jāne sakhyās tava mayi manaḥ saṃbhṛtasneham asmād itthaṃbhūtāṃ prathamavirahe tām ahaṃ tarkayāmi /
analyzed: jāne sakhyāḥ tava mayi manaḥ saṃbhṛta sneham asmāt itthaṃbhūtām prathama virahe tām aham tarkayāmi
translated: I know that your friend's mind is filled with affection for me, so I infer that she is in such a state in her first separation.

original: vācālaṃ māṃ na khalu subhagaṃmanyabhāvaḥ karoti pratyakṣaṃ te nikhilam acirād bhrātar uktaṃ mayā yat // //
analyzed: vācālam mām na khalu subhagaṃmanya bhāvaḥ karoti pratyakṣam te nikhilam acirāt bhrātar uktam mayā yat
translated: My speech, O fortunate one, does not make you think me arrogant, my brother, all that I have said will soon be evident to you.

original: sā saṃnyastābharaṇam abalā pelavaṃ dhārayantī śayyotsaṅge nihitam asakṛd duḥkhaduḥkhena gātram /
analyzed: sā saṃnyasta ābharaṇam abalā pelavam dhārayantī śayyā utsaṅge nihitam asakṛt duḥkha duḥkhena gātram
translated: That helpless one, having removed her ornaments, wearing a thin garment, repeatedly placing her body, causing grief, on the couch,

original: tvām apy asraṃ navajalamayaṃ mocayiṣyaty avaśyaṃ prāyaḥ sarvo bhavati karuṇāvṛttir ārdrāntarātmā // //🔽ruddhāpāṅgaprasaram alakair añjanasnehaśūnyaṃ pratyādeśād api ca madhuno vismṛtabhrūvilāsam /🔽tvayy āsanne nayanam uparispandi śaṅke mṛgākṣyā mīnakṣobhākulakuvalayaśrītulām eṣyatīti // //
analyzed: tvām api asram nava jala mayam mocayiṣyati avaśyam prāyas sarvaḥ bhavati karuṇā vṛttiḥ ārdra antarātmā  ruddha apāṅga prasaram alakaiḥ añjana sneha śūnyam pratyādeśāt api ca madhunaḥ vismṛta bhrū vilāsam  tvayi āsanne nayanam upari spandi śaṅke mṛga akṣyāḥ mīna kṣobha ākula kuvalaya śrī tulām eṣyati iti
translated: The fresh water of her tears will certainly set you free, for generally the inner soul of the compassionate is moist.🔽Her eye, with the flow of its corners obstructed by her locks, devoid of the moisture of collyrium, and with the play of its brows forgotten even at the bidding of wine,🔽I fear, when you are near, will rise to the level of the beauty of a blue lotus agitated by the stirring of a fish, its upper part quivering.

original: vāmo vāsyāḥ kararuhapadair mucyamāno madīyair muktājālaṃ ciraparicitaṃ tyājito daivagatyā /
analyzed: vāmaḥ vā asyāḥ kararuha padaiḥ mucyamānaḥ madīyaiḥ muktā jālam cira paricitam tyājitaḥ daivagatyā
translated: Her left thigh, being released by my fingers marked with the lines of my nails, and abandoned by the string of pearls, long familiar, by the course of fate,

original: saṃbhogānte mama samucito hastasaṃvāhanānāṃ yāsyaty ūruḥ sarasakadalīstambhagauraś calatvam // //
analyzed: saṃbhoga ante mama samucitaḥ hasta saṃvāhanānām yāsyati ūruḥ sarasa kadalī stambha gauraḥ cala tvam
translated: will, at the end of our enjoyment, fit for the caresses of my hands, assume the swaying grace of a fresh plantain trunk.

original: tasmin kāle jalada dayitā labdhanidrā yadi syād anvāsyaināṃ stanitavimukho yāmamātraṃ sahasva /
analyzed: tasmin kāle jalada dayitā labdha nidrā yadi syāt anvāsya enām stanita vimukhaḥ yāma mātram sahasva
translated: At that time, O cloud, if your beloved should fall asleep, attend upon her, and for just a watch, be averse to thundering.

original: mā bhūd asyāḥ praṇayini mayi svapnalabdhe kathaṃ cit sadyaḥ kaṇṭhacyutabhujalatāgranthi gāḍhopagūḍham // //
analyzed: mā bhūt asyāḥ praṇayini mayi svapna labdhe katham cit sadyas kaṇṭha cyuta bhuja latā granthi gāḍha upagūḍham
translated: Let there be no sudden close embrace, with the knot of her creeper-like arms on her bosom loosened, in me, somehow gained by her in a dream, as her loving one.

original: tām utthāpya svajalakaṇikāśītalenānilena pratyāśvastāṃ samam abhinavair jālakair mālatīnām /
analyzed: tām utthāpya sva jala kaṇikā śītalena anilena pratyāśvastām samam abhinavaiḥ jālakaiḥ mālatīnām
translated: Having raised her, and comforted her with a breeze cool with your own water-drops, and at the same time with fresh garlands of jasmine flowers,

original: vidyudgarbhe nihitanayanāṃ tvatsanāthe gavākṣe vaktuṃ dhīrastanitavacanair māninīṃ prakramethāḥ // //
analyzed: vidyut garbhe nihita nayanām tvad sanāthe gavākṣe vaktum dhīra stanita vacanaiḥ māninīm prakramethāḥ
translated: with your eyes placed in the lightning, you should approach the jealous woman in the window protected by you, and speak to her with words of thunder.

original: bhartur mitraṃ priyam avidhave viddhi mām ambuvāhaṃ tatsaṃdeśān manasi nihitād āgataṃ tvatsamīpam /
analyzed: bhartuḥ mitram priyam avidhave viddhi mām ambuvāham tad saṃdeśāt manasi nihitāt āgatam tvad samīpam
translated: Know me, O cloud, to be the friend and dear messenger of your master, come to you from his side, where his message is kept in mind.

original: yo vṛndāni tvarayati pathi śrāmyatāṃ proṣitānāṃ mandrasnigdhair dhvanibhir abalāveṇimokṣotsukāni // //🔽ity ākhyāte pavanatanayaṃ maithilīvonmukhī sā tvām utkaṇṭhocchvasitahṛdayā vīkṣya saṃbhāvya caiva /
analyzed: yaḥ vṛndāni tvarayati pathi śrāmyatām proṣitānām mandra snigdhaiḥ dhvanibhiḥ abalā veṇi mokṣa utsukāni  iti ākhyāte pavanatanayam maithilī iva unmukhī sā tvām utkaṇṭhā ucchvasita hṛdayā vīkṣya saṃbhāvya ca eva
translated: I am he who hastens the flocks of travellers weary on the way, eager to untie the braids of their wives, with my sweet and gentle sounds.🔽When the daughter of Mithila, with her heart throbbing with longing, sees you, O friend, and recognizes you, after this has been told to her by the son of the Wind,

original: śroṣyaty asmāt param avahitā somya sīmantinīnāṃ kāntodantaḥ suhṛdupanataḥ saṃgamāt kiṃ cid ūnaḥ // //
analyzed: śroṣyati asmāt param avahitā somya sīmantinīnām kānta udantaḥ suhṛd upanataḥ saṃgamāt kim cit ūnaḥ
translated: she will listen attentively to what follows, O gentle one, the story of her lover, a friend related by me, slightly inferior to the meeting (with her).

original: tām āyuṣmān mama ca vacanād ātmanā copakartuṃ brūyād evaṃ tava sahacaro rāmagiryāśramasthaḥ /
analyzed: tām āyuṣmān mama ca vacanāt ātmanā ca upakartum brūyāt evam tava sahacaraḥ rāmagiri āśrama sthaḥ
translated: You should speak thus to her, O long-lived one, to help me and yourself, on my behalf and on your own: 'Your companion, staying in the hermitage on the Ramagiri mountain,

original: avyāpannaḥ kuśalam abale pṛcchati tvāṃ viyuktaḥ pūrvāśāsyaṃ sulabhavipadāṃ prāṇinām etad eva // //
analyzed: avyāpannaḥ kuśalam abale pṛcchati tvām viyuktaḥ pūrva āśāsyam sulabha vipadām prāṇinām etat eva
translated: Uninjured, he asks you, O weak one, about your welfare, being separated from you, O you whose limbs are delicate, O you who are dear to me. This is the first thing to be wished for by living beings, who are subject to misfortune.

original: aṅgenāṅgaṃ tanu ca tanunā gāḍhataptena taptaṃ sāsreṇāsradravam aviratotkaṇṭham utkaṇṭhitena /
analyzed: aṅgena aṅgam tanu ca tanunā gāḍha taptena taptam sa asreṇa asra dravam avirata utkaṇṭham utkaṇṭhitena
translated: With limb touching limb, with his delicate body burning with heat, with tears in his eyes, with longing unabated,

original: uṣṇocchvāsaṃ samadhikatarocchvāsinā dūravartī saṃkalpais te viśati vidhinā vairiṇā ruddhamārgaḥ // //
analyzed: uṣṇa ucchvāsam samadhikatara ucchvāsinā dūra vartī saṃkalpaiḥ te viśati vidhinā vairiṇā ruddha mārgaḥ
translated: with hot sighs, with sighs more intense still, the one far away, with his path obstructed by fate, his enemy, enters you with his thoughts.

original: śabdākhyeyaṃ yad api kila te yaḥ sakhīnāṃ purastāt karṇe lolaḥ kathayitum abhūd ānanasparśalobhāt /
analyzed: śabda ākhyeyam yat api kila te yaḥ sakhīnām purastāt karṇe lolaḥ kathayitum abhūt ānana sparśa lobhāt
translated: That which is to be told by word, which indeed was formerly in your friend's presence, which was eager to speak in her ear out of a desire to touch your face,

original: so 'tikrāntaḥ śravaṇaviṣayaṃ locanānām agamyas tvām utkaṇṭhāviracitapadaṃ manmukhenedam āha // //
analyzed: saḥ u tikrāntaḥ śravaṇa viṣayam locanānām agamyaḥ tvām utkaṇṭhā viracita padam mad mukhena idam āha
translated: that has passed beyond the range of hearing, is inaccessible to the eyes, and speaks to you through my mouth these words, composed out of longing.

original: śyāmāsv aṅgaṃ cakitahariṇaprekṣite dṛṣṭipātaṃ gaṇḍacchāyāṃ śaśini śikhināṃ varhabhāreṣu keśān /
analyzed: śyāmāsu aṅgam cakita hariṇa prekṣite dṛṣṭi pātam gaṇḍa chāyām śaśini śikhinām varha bhāreṣu keśān
translated: In dark-complexioned women I see your body, in the sidelong glances of startled deer I see your glances, in the moon I see the beauty of your cheeks, in the crests of peacocks I see your hair,

original: utpaśyāmi pratanuṣu nadīvīciṣu bhrūvilāsān hantaikasthaṃ kva cid api na te bhīru sādṛśyam asti // //
analyzed: utpaśyāmi pratanuṣu nadī vīciṣu bhrū vilāsān hanta ekastham kva cit api na te bhīru sādṛśyam asti
translated: in the slender waves of the river I see your playful eyebrows. Alas, O timid one, nowhere is there a complete likeness of you.

original: tvām ālikhya praṇayakupitāṃ dhāturāgaiḥ śilāyām ātmānaṃ te caraṇapatitaṃ yāvad icchāmi kartum /
analyzed: tvām ālikhya praṇaya kupitām dhātu rāgaiḥ śilāyām ātmānam te caraṇa patitam yāvat icchāmi kartum
translated: Having painted you on a rock with mineral colors, angry in love, I wish to make myself fall at your feet.

original: asrais tāvan muhur upacitair dṛṣṭir ālipyate me krūras tasminn api na sahate saṃgamaṃ nau kṛtāntaḥ // //
analyzed: asraiḥ tāvat muhur upacitaiḥ dṛṣṭiḥ ālipyate me krūraḥ tasmin api na sahate saṃgamam nau kṛtāntaḥ
translated: But as long as I do this, my eyes are smeared again and again with tears that have gathered. Cruel fate does not allow us to meet, even in that.

original: mām ākāśapraṇihitabhujaṃ nirdayāśleṣahetor labdhāyās te katham api sati svapnasaṃdarśaneṣu /🔽paśyantīnāṃ na khalu bahuśo na sthalīdevatānāṃ muktāsthūlās tarukisalayeṣv asruleśāḥ patanti // //
analyzed: mām ākāśa praṇihita bhujam nirdaya āśleṣa hetoḥ labdhāyāḥ te katham api sati svapna saṃdarśaneṣu  paśyantīnām na khalu bahuśas na sthalīdevatānām muktā sthūlāḥ taru kisalayeṣu asru leśāḥ patanti
translated: When I have stretched out my arms in the air, in order to embrace you mercilessly, and you have somehow been obtained in the visions of a dream,🔽the drops of tears, thick as pearls, falling on the treetops are certainly seen by the many local deities.

original: bhittvā sadyaḥ kisalayapuṭān devadārudrumāṇāṃ ye tatkṣīrasrutisurabhayo dakṣiṇena pravṛttāḥ /
analyzed: bhittvā sadyas kisalaya puṭān devadāru drumāṇām ye tad kṣīra sruti surabhayaḥ dakṣiṇena pravṛttāḥ
translated: Those breezes from the Himālayas, fragrant with the flow of the sap of the devadāru trees, which have suddenly burst open their leaf-buds and are blowing from the south,

original: āliṅgyante guṇavati mayā te tuṣārādrivātāḥ pūrvaspṛṣṭaṃ yadi kila bhaved aṅgam ebhis taveti // //
analyzed: āliṅgyante guṇavati mayā te tuṣārādri vātāḥ pūrva spṛṣṭam yadi kila bhavet aṅgam ebhiḥ tava iti
translated: I embrace them, O virtuous one, thinking that if they have touched your body, they will have touched mine.

original: saṃkṣipyeran kṣaṇa iva kathaṃ dīrghayāmās triyāmāḥ sarvāvasthāsv ahar api kathaṃ mandamandātapaṃ syāt /
analyzed: saṃkṣipyeran kṣaṇaḥ iva katham dīrgha yāmāḥ triyāmāḥ sarva avasthāsu ahar api katham manda manda ātapam syāt
translated: How can the three watches of the night be shortened to a moment, and how can the day be with very mild sunshine in all conditions?

original: itthaṃ cetaś caṭulanayane durlabhaprārthanaṃ me gāḍhoṣmābhiḥ kṛtam aśaraṇaṃ tvadviyogavyathābhiḥ // //
analyzed: ittham cetaḥ caṭula nayane durlabha prārthanam me gāḍha uṣmābhiḥ kṛtam aśaraṇam tvad viyoga vyathābhiḥ
translated: Thus, O you with restless eyes, my heart, which is helpless, has been made the object of an impossible request by the intense pangs of separation from you.

original: nanv ātmānaṃ bahu vigaṇayann ātmanā nāvalambe tat kalyāṇi tvam api sutarāṃ mā gamaḥ kātaratvam /
analyzed: nanu ātmānam bahu vigaṇayan ātmanā nā avalambe tat kalyāṇi tvam api sutarām mā gamaḥ kātara tvam
translated: Indeed, considering myself to be of little worth, I do not rely on myself. Therefore, O fortunate one, you should be all the more fearless.

original: kasyātyantaṃ sukham upanataṃ duḥkham ekāntato vā nīcair gacchaty upari ca daśā cakranemikrameṇa // //🔽śāpānto me bhujagaśayanād utthite śārṅgapāṇau māsān anyān gamaya caturo locane mīlayitvā /
analyzed: kasya atyantam sukham upanatam duḥkham ekāntataḥ vā nīcais gacchati upari ca daśā cakra nemi krameṇa  śāpa antaḥ me bhujaga śayanāt utthite śārṅgapāṇau māsān anyān gamaya caturaḥ locane mīlayitvā
translated: Whose happiness is complete, or whose sorrow is absolute? The state of affairs goes up and down like the rim of a wheel.🔽When I have finished my curse, and the wielder of the Śārṅga bow has arisen from his serpent couch, pass the next four months with your eyes closed, O my beloved.

original: paścād āvāṃ virahaguṇitaṃ taṃ tam ātmābhilāṣaṃ nirvekṣyāvaḥ pariṇataśaraccandrikāsu kṣapāsu // //
analyzed: paścāt āvām viraha guṇitam tam tam ātma abhilāṣam nirvekṣyāvaḥ pariṇata śarad candrikāsu kṣapāsu
translated: Then, in the nights of autumn with the moon shining brightly, we shall enjoy the pleasures we have longed for in our separation.

original: bhūyaś cāha tvam api śayane kaṇṭhalagnā purā me nidrāṃ gatvā kim api rudatī sasvanaṃ viprabuddhā /
analyzed: bhūyas ca āha tvam api śayane kaṇṭha lagnā purā me nidrām gatvā kim api rudatī sa svanam viprabuddhā
translated: And again you said: 'Formerly, when you were embracing me on the bed, I fell asleep and woke up crying out in my sleep.

original: sāntarhāsaṃ kathitam asakṛt pṛcchataś ca tvayā me dṛṣṭaḥ svapne kitava ramayan kām api tvaṃ mayeti // //
analyzed: sa antarhāsam kathitam asakṛt pṛcchataḥ ca tvayā me dṛṣṭaḥ svapne kitava ramayan kām api tvam mayā iti
translated: And when I asked you again and again, you said with a smile: I saw you in a dream, O gambler, amusing yourself with some other woman.'

original: etasmān māṃ kuśalinam abhijñānadānād viditvā mā kaulīnād asitanayane mayy aviśvāsinī bhūḥ /
analyzed: etasmāt mām kuśalinam abhijñāna dānāt viditvā mā kaulīnāt asita nayane mayi aviśvāsinī bhūḥ
translated: Knowing me to be well from this token, do not be distrustful of me, O you with eyes dark like the blue lotus, out of a sense of family honour.

original: snehān āhuḥ kim api virahahrāsinas te hy abhogād iṣṭe vastuny upacitarasāḥ premarāśībhavanti // //
analyzed: snehān āhuḥ kim api viraha hrāsinaḥ te hi abhogāt iṣṭe vastuni upacita rasāḥ prema rāśībhavanti
translated: They say that love, though diminishing in separation, is increased by enjoyment; for, when the object of love is near, love becomes a heap of love.

original: kac cit somya vyavasitam idaṃ bandhukṛtyaṃ tvayā me pratyākhyātuṃ na khalu bhavato dhīratāṃ tarkayāmi /
analyzed: kac cit somya vyavasitam idam bandhu kṛtyam tvayā me pratyākhyātum na khalu bhavataḥ dhīra tām tarkayāmi
translated: O dear one, I hope you have decided to do this favour to me? I do not think your firmness can be shaken.

original: niḥśabdo 'pi pradiśasi jalaṃ yācitaś cātakebhyaḥ pratyuktaṃ hi praṇayiṣu satām īpsitārthakriyaiva // //
analyzed: niḥśabdaḥ u pi pradiśasi jalam yācitaḥ cātakebhyaḥ pratyuktam hi praṇayiṣu satām īpsita artha kriyā eva
translated: Though silent, you give water when asked by the chātaka birds; for the good, when entreated, accomplish the desired object of their friends by their very nature.

original: etat kṛtvā priyam anucitaprārthanāvartmano me sauhārdād vā vidhura iti vā mayy anukrośabuddhyā /
analyzed: etat kṛtvā priyam anucita prārthanā vartmanaḥ me sauhārdāt vā vidhuraḥ iti vā mayi anukrośa buddhyā
translated: Having done this favour to me, who am on the path of making improper requests, either out of friendship or out of pity for me who am in distress,

original: iṣṭān deśān vicara jalada prāvṛṣā saṃbhṛtaśrīr mā bhūd evaṃ kṣaṇam api ca te vidyutā viprayogaḥ // //
analyzed: iṣṭān deśān vicara jalada prāvṛṣā saṃbhṛta śrīḥ mā bhūt evam kṣaṇam api ca te vidyutā viprayogaḥ
translated: wander through the desired regions, O cloud, your glory increased by the rains; may there be no separation from the lightning even for a moment.
